voca.means_en:
A butcher is a shopkeeper who cuts up and sells meat. Some butchers also kill animals for meat and make foods such as sausages and meat pies.
You can refer to someone as a butcher when they have killed a lot of people in a very cruel way, and you want to express your horror and disgust.
A butcher or a butcher's is a shop where meat is sold.
To butcher an animal means to kill it and cut it up for meat.
You can say that someone has butchered people when they have killed a lot of people in a very cruel way, and you want to express your horror and disgust.
She is allowed to take his mom's money by attorney.\n

A cab is a taxi.
The cab of a truck or train is the front part in which the driver sits.
A : I'm at the station. I'm so sorry for being late, but the train was late. I'm waiting for a cab.

acute depression resulting from being isolated or sharing cramped quarters in the wilderness, esp during the long northern winter
If I stay in this house one more day I'm going to have cabin fever.
Ken : Yesterday I had cabin fever so bad I yelled at my family for no reason at all.
A Caesarean or a Caesarean section is an operation in which a baby is lifted out of a woman's womb through an opening cut in her abdomen.\n

voca.means_ko:

전화(통화), 들름, 방문, 요청, 요구
voca.means_en:
call / cry out / exclaim / blurt / burst out
If you call someone or something by a particular name or title, you give them that name or title.
If you call someone or something a particular thing, you suggest they are that thing or describe them as that thing.
If you call something, you say it in a loud voice, because you are trying to attract someone's attention.
If you call someone, you telephone them.
If you call someone such as a doctor or the police, you ask them to come to you, usually by telephoning them.
If you call someone, you ask them to come to you by shouting to them.
When you make a telephone call, you telephone someone.
If there is a call for something, someone demands that it should happen.

voca.means_ko: 무승부로 하다, 비긴것으로 하다\n~을 그만하기로 하다
voca.means_en:
decide to end an argument, a disagreement, etc. at a point where both sides are equal
It's five o'clock. I'm going to call it quits and go home.
Terry: Just one more mile and I'm calling it quits.

voca.means_ko: (특히 위급한 상황에서) ~를 부르다, 호출하다\n파업을 명하다, 권하다
voca.means_en:
to ask somebody to come to help you, when there is an emergency
to order or ask workers to stop work as a protest
(for something) to criticize somebody's actions

calm / calmness
A calm person does not show or feel any worry, anger, or excitement.
If someone says that a place is calm, they mean that it is free from fighting or public disorder, when trouble has recently occurred there or had been expected.
If the sea or a lake is calm, the water is not moving very much and there are no big waves.
Calm weather is pleasant weather with little or no wind.
If you calm someone, you do something to make them feel less angry, worried, or excited.
To calm a situation means to reduce the amount of trouble, violence, or panic there is.
He felt calm and safe as the stag sped like a white comet throught the wintry countryside.
A : It'll help calm your cough.

voca.means_en:
A camp is a collection of huts and other buildings that is provided for a particular group of people, such as refugees, prisoners, or soldiers, as a place to live or stay.
A camp is an outdoor area with buildings, tents, or caravans where people stay on holiday.
A camp is a collection of tents or caravans where people are living or staying, usually temporarily while they are travelling.
You can refer to a group of people who all support a particular person, policy, or idea as a particular camp.
If you camp somewhere, you stay or live there for a short time in a tent or caravan, or in the open air.
If you describe someone's behaviour, performance, or style of dress as camp, you mean that it is exaggerated and amusing, often in a way that is thought to be typical of some male homosexuals.

Cancer is a serious disease in which cells in a person's body increase rapidly in an uncontrolled way, producing abnormal growths.\nCancer is one of the twelve signs of the zodiac. Its symbol is a crab. People who are born approximately between the 21st of June and the 22nd of July come under this sign.\n

Capital is a large sum of money which you use to start a business, or which you invest in order to make more money.
You can use capital to refer to buildings or machinery which are necessary to produce goods or to make companies more efficient, but which do not make money directly.
Capital is the part of an amount of money borrowed or invested which does not include interest.
The capital of a country is the city or town where its government or parliament meets.
If a place is the capital of a particular industry or activity, it is the place that is most famous for it, because it happens in that place more than anywhere else.
Capitals or capital letters are written or printed letters in the form which is used at the beginning of sentences or names. 'T', 'B', and 'F' are capitals.
A capital offence is one that is so serious that the person who commits it can be punished by death.

If you are careless, you do not pay enough attention to what you are doing, and so you make mistakes, or cause harm or damage.
If you say that someone is careless of something such as their health or appearance, you mean that they do not seem to be concerned about it, or do nothing to keep it in a good condition.
"But a warning, my boy: you are hasty and careless with your magic rhymes.

Carrots are long, thin, orange-coloured vegetables. They grow under the ground, and have green shoots above the ground.\nSomething that is offered to people in order to persuade them to do something can be referred to as a carrot. Something that is meant to persuade people not to do something can be referred to in the same sentence as a 'stick'.\n

voca.means_ko: ~을 가져가 버리다, 운반해 가다, \n(파도, 바닷물이 배에서) ~을 휩쓸어 가다\n~의 넋을 잃게 하다, ~을 열중하게 하다, ~을 흥붑시키다
voca.means_en: "Don't get carried away," whispered Jake.\n

The cast of a play or film is all the people who act in it.
A cast is a model that has been made by pouring a liquid such as plaster or hot metal onto something or into something, so that when it hardens it has the same shape as that thing.
A cast is the same as a plaster cast.
To cast an actor in a play or film means to choose them to act a particular role in it.
To cast someone in a particular way or as a particular thing means to describe them in that way or suggest they are that thing.
If you cast your eyes or cast a look in a particular direction, you look quickly in that direction.
If something casts a light or shadow somewhere, it causes it to appear there.
To cast doubt on something means to cause people to be unsure about it.
After you left, Arthur defeated him, but not before Mordred's Dark Wizard cast a spell over the whole kingdom.
A : And he has to put up with a cast on his leg for 3 weeks.

별견하다, 때마침 만나다, (병에) 걸리다
잡기, 포획량
voca.means_en:
catch - caught - caught
see / spot / catch / glimpse / clap / lay / set eyes on
If you catch a person or animal, you capture them after chasing them, or by using a trap, net, or other device.
If you catch an object that is moving through the air, you seize it with your hands.
If you catch a part of someone's body, you take or seize it with your hand, often in order to stop them going somewhere.
If one thing catches another, it hits it accidentally or manages to hit it.
If something catches on or in an object or if an object catches something, it accidentally becomes attached to the object or stuck in it.
If you catch yourself doing something, especially something surprising, you suddenly become aware that you are doing it.
"We'll paddle out to catch a big wave!" said Boka.

voca.means_ko: (먼저간 사람을) 따라잡다, 따라가다\n(정도나 수준이 앞선 것을) 따라잡다
voca.means_en:
to spend extra time doing all the work, tasks, etc. that you should have done earlier
to find out about things that have happened
to reach somebody/something ahead of you by going faster than them/it
to reach the same level or standard as somebody/something else that was better or more advanced
Amy: I'd love to but I've got some catching up to do.

cautious / careful
Someone who is cautious acts very carefully in order to avoid possible danger.
If you describe someone's attitude or reaction as cautious, you mean that it is limited or careful.
A cavity is a space or hole in something such as a solid object or a person's body.\nIn dentistry, a cavity is a hole in a tooth, caused by decay.\n

If you celebrate, you do something enjoyable because of a special occasion or to mark someone's success.
If an organization or country is celebrating an anniversary, it has existed for that length of time and is doing something special because of it.
When priests celebrate Holy Communion or Mass, they officially perform the actions and ceremonies that are involved.
A cellar is a room underneath a building, which is often used for storing things in.\nA person's or restaurant's cellar is the collection of different wines that they have.\n

voca.means_ko: [쎄메퉤어뤼]\n(특히 교회 옆에 있지 않은) 묘지, 묘역, 무덤, 공동 묘지
voca.means_en: A cemetery is a place where dead people's bodies or their ashes are buried.\n

If you describe someone or something as cerebral, you mean that they are intellectual rather than emotional.
Cerebral means relating to the brain.
This chef is incorporating marijuana in 5-star fine dining.
This is a cerebral experience. Whit each bite, you're literally changing your brain chemistry.

surely / certainly
You use certainly to emphasize what you are saying when you are making a statement.
You use certainly when you are agreeing with what someone has said.
You say certainly not when you want to say 'no' in a strong way.

[췌임버r]
방, 침실, 공무 집행실, 회의장

실내용의, 실내 음악의
voca.means_en:
A chamber is a large room, especially one that is used for formal meetings.
You can refer to a country's parliament or to one section of it as a chamber.
A chamber is a room designed and equipped for a particular purpose.

voca.means_ko:
[^촤-취]
(상품, 서비스에 대한) 요금, 
(경찰의) 기소, 고발, 
(사람, 일에 대한) 책임, 담당, 
습격, 돌격, 
(요금, 값을) 청구하다, 채우다, 돌격하다
요금, 충전, 책임
voca.means_en:
rate / charge / fee / rent / dues / toll / rental / tariff
If you charge someone an amount of money, you ask them to pay that amount for something that you have sold to them or done for them.
To charge something to a person or organization means to tell the people providing it to send the bill to that person or organization. To charge something to someone's account means to add it to their account so they can pay for it later.
When the police charge someone, they formally accuse them of having done something illegal.
If you charge someone with doing something wrong or unpleasant, you publicly say that they have done it.
If you charge towards someone or something, you move quickly and aggressively towards them.
To charge a battery means to pass an electrical current through it in order to make it more powerful or to make it last longer.
A charge is an amount of money that you have to pay for a service.
B : They only gave it a once-over and charged me 500 bucks.

voca.means_ko: [^촤r밍]\n매력적인, 멋진\n대단한 (누군가의 행동에 대한 불만을 반어적으로 나타냄)
voca.means_en:
If you say that something is charming, you mean that it is very pleasant or attractive.
If you describe someone as charming, you mean they behave in a friendly, pleasant way that makes people like them.
"How charming. I've caught a Teddy. I think he'll make a wonderful pet, don't you?"

used to refuse an offer or invitation but to say that you will accept it later
I took a rain check.
She didn't have time, soso she had to take a rain check.
I'm busy today, so can I take a rain check?
There's something we have to check on!\n
to take somebody's name when they arrive at a hotel or an airport, look at their ticket, etc.\n

an examination to see if something is in order
a medical examination, esp one taken at regular intervals to verify a normal state of health or discover a disease in its early stages
check up to investigate or make an inquiry into (a person's character, evidence, etc), esp when suspicions have been aroused
"I'll go first!" said Annie cheerfully.\n

Cheesy food is food that tastes or smells of cheese.
If you describe something as cheesy, you mean that it is cheap, unpleasant, or insincere.
When Rocky came back with the pizza, the class grew quiet, everyone chewing teeny-weeny cheesy squares fo Gino's pizza and listening to Mr. Todd read them a chapter from a book about a pepperoni pizza-eating dog.
Chess is a game for two people, played on a chessboard. Each player has 16 pieces, including a king. Your aim is to move your pieces so that your opponent's king cannot escape being taken.\n
A person's childhood is the period of their life when they are a child.\n

voca.means_ko:
[췰]
쌀쌀해지다, 오싹해지다, 춥게하다
냉기, 차가움, 한기, 오한
차가운, 쌀쌀한
voca.means_en:
When you chill something or when it chills, you lower its temperature so that it becomes colder but does not freeze.
When cold weather or something cold chills a person or a place, it makes that person or that place feel very cold.
If something sends a chill through you, it gives you a sudden feeling of fear or anxiety.
A chill is a mild illness which can give you a slight fever and headache.
Chill weather is cold and unpleasant.
As he stared at the ship's flag, a chill went through him.

voca.means_ko: [췰뤼]\n차가운, 쌀쌀한, 냉담한, 오싹하게 하는\n싸늘하게, 차게, 쌀쌀하게
voca.means_en:
cold / cool / freezing / chilly / lukewarm / tepid
Something that is chilly is unpleasantly cold.
If you feel chilly, you feel rather cold.
You say that relations between people are chilly or that a person's response is chilly when they are not friendly, welcoming, or enthusiastic.
I feel chilly.

task / duties / mission / job / assignment / chore
A chore is a task that you must do but that you find unpleasant or boring.
Chores are tasks such as cleaning, washing, and ironing that have to be done regularly at home.
"We've finished our chores," said Kama.
"Our mission has to be harder than just doing chores," said Jack.

A chronic illness or disability lasts for a very long time. Compare acute.
You can describe someone's bad habits or behaviour as chronic when they have behaved like that for a long time and do not seem to be able to stop themselves.
A chronic situation or problem is very severe and unpleasant.

I don't want to suffer from chronic pain.
My chronic pain gets worse when it rains.
She took medicine for the chronic pain.
He's got stunning looks and he is a class act.\nThe principal is a class act (man) who has greatly improved the school.\n
Your classmates are students who are in the same class as you at school or college.\nTerry: It's not bad but there's a lot of writing to do. Sometimes it's hard to keep up with my classmates.\n
to clean the inside of something thoroughly\nto use up or take all somebody's money; to take or buy the whole supply of something that somebody has\n
cough slightly, especially before speaking or to attract somebody's attention\n
Clippers are a tool used for cutting small amounts from something, especially from someone's hair or nails.\n
to make or move along with a sound as of a horse's hooves striking the ground\na sound of this nature\n

at a short distance (from somebody/something)
Alright. Text me when you are close by.
His surfboard was close by.
These countries are close by and they have a lot to offer.

A clue to a problem or mystery is something that helps you to find the answer to it.
A clue is an object or piece of information that helps someone solve a crime.
A clue in a crossword or game is information which is given to help you to find the answer to a question.
I wonder if she left any other clues.
"First, we have to find a clue that tells us where to begin" he said.
"Didn't Mr. Haney give you any clues at all?" Francine asked.

hold / hold on / cling / clutch / grip / grasp / clasp / hang on
If you clutch at something or clutch something, you hold it tightly, usually because you are afraid or anxious.
If someone is in another person's clutches, that person has captured them or has power over them.
He clutched the gold medallion
She clutched the mammoth's ears to keep from falling off.

A coat is a piece of clothing with long sleeves which you wear over your other clothes when you go outside.
An animal's coat is the fur or hair on its body.
A coat of paint or varnish is a thin layer of it on a surface.
If you coat something with a substance or in a substance, you cover it with a thin layer of the substance.
They wore blue coats and green coats, white gowns and yellow gowns.
A : I need this by COB.\nB : I haven't finished yet. It still needs some work.\n

voca.means_en: A person's cohorts are their friends, supporters, or associates.\n

A coil of rope or wire is a length of it that has been wound into a series of loops.
A coil is one loop in a series of loops.
A coil is a thick spiral of wire through which an electrical current passes.
The coil is a contraceptive device used by women. It is fitted inside a woman's womb, usually for several months or years.
If you coil something, you wind it into a series of loops or into the shape of a ring. If it coils around something, it forms loops or a ring.

Your colleagues are the people you work with, especially in a professional job.\nMy friend is in trouble, my colleague is in trouble with the boss, and I decide: "You know what? I'm going to go talk to the boss and make sure he understands that my friend is a good worker."\n

voca.means_en:
A collection of things is a group of similar things that you have deliberately acquired, usually over a period of time.
A collection of stories, poems, or articles is a number of them published in one book.
A collection of things is a group of things.
A fashion designer's new collection consists of the new clothes they have designed for the next season.
Collection is the act of collecting something from a place or from people.

colour / shade / tone / hue / tint / tinge
The colour of something is the appearance that it has as a result of the way in which it reflects light. Red, blue, and green are colours.
A colour is a substance you use to give something a particular colour. Dyes and make-up are sometimes referred to as colours.
Someone's colour is the colour of their skin. People often use colour in this way to refer to a person's race.
Colour is a quality that makes something especially interesting or exciting.
If you colour something, you use something such as dyes or paint to change its colour.
If someone colours, their face becomes redder than it normally is, usually because they are embarrassed.
be treated as the most important person or thing in somebody's life\n

I didn't know this would come in so handy.
Extra water always comes in handy.

when flowers come out, they open

stop moving\nA huge yellow leaf fluttered through the open window and came to rest at Jack's feet.\n

to appear above the ground
when the sun or moon comes up, it rises in the sky

voca.means_en: If you describe someone's behaviour as commendable, you approve of it or are praising it.\n

You use comparative to show that you are judging something against a previous or different situation. For example, comparative calm is a situation which is calmer than before or calmer than the situation in other places.
A comparative study is a study that involves the comparison of two or more things of the same kind.
In grammar, the comparative form of an adjective or adverb shows that something has more of a quality than something else has. For example, 'bigger' is the comparative form of 'big', and 'more quickly' is the comparative form of 'quickly'. Compare superlative.
If a situation, a rule, or a person compels you to do something, they force you to do it.\nIf you feel compelled to do something, you feel that you must do it, because it is the right thing to do.\n

voca.means_en:
interesting / fascinating / compelling / stimulating / gripping / absorbing
A compelling argument or reason is one that convinces you that something is true or that something should be done.
If you describe something such as a film or book, or someone's appearance, as compelling, you mean you want to keep looking at it or reading it because you find it so interesting.

When one firm or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its own goods in preference to those of the other firm or country. You can also say that two firms or countries compete.
If you compete with someone for something, you try to get it for yourself and stop the other person getting it. You can also say that two people compete for something.
If you compete in a contest or a game, you take part in it.
Competency means the same as competence.\n

Competition is a situation in which two or more people or groups are trying to get something which not everyone can have.
The competition is the person or people you are competing with.
Competition is an activity involving two or more firms, in which each firm tries to get people to buy its own goods in preference to the other firms' goods.
The competition is the goods that a rival organization is selling.
A competition is an event in which many people take part in order to find out who is best at a particular activity.
A company's competitors are companies who are trying to sell similar goods or services to the same people.\nA competitor is a person who takes part in a competition or contest.\n

If people or things complement each other, they are different or do something different, which makes them a good combination.
Something that is a complement to something else complements it.
The complement of things or people that something has is the number of things or people that it normally has, which enable it to function properly.

building / property / premises / complex / structure / block / edifice
Something that is complex has many different parts, and is therefore often difficult to understand.
In grammar, a complex sentence contains one or more subordinate clauses as well as a main clause. Compare compound.
A complex is a group of buildings designed for a particular purpose, or one large building divided into several smaller areas.
If someone has a complex about something, they have a mental or emotional problem relating to it, often because of an unpleasant experience in the past.
Complexity is the state of having many different parts connected or related to each other in a complicated way.\n
understand / see / get / follow / grasp / comprehend\nIf you cannot comprehend something, you cannot understand it.\n

Concern is worry about a situation. / A concern is a fact or situation that worries you.
Someone's concern with something is their feeling that it is important.
Concern for someone is a feeling that you want them to be happy, safe, and well. If you do something out of concern for someone, you do it because you want them to be happy, safe, and well.
If something concerns you, it worries you.
If a situation or problem is your concern, it is something that you have a duty or responsibility to be involved with.
If you concern yourself with something, you give it attention because you think that it is important.
You can refer to a company or business as a concern, usually when you are describing what type of company or business it is.
If something such as a book or a piece of information concerns a particular subject, it is about that subject.
When it comes to travelling, safety is a major concern.

A cone is a shape with a circular base and smooth curved sides ending in a point at the top.
A cone is the fruit of a tree such as a pine or fir.
A cone is a thin, cone-shaped biscuit that is used for holding ice cream. You can also refer to an ice cream that you eat in this way as a cone.

If someone confesses to doing something wrong, they admit that they did it.
If someone confesses or confesses their sins, they tell God or a priest about their sins so that they can be forgiven.
You use expressions like 'I confess', 'I must confess', or 'I have to confess' to apologize slightly for admitting something you are ashamed of or that you think might offend or annoy someone.
'I did it,' Jack confessed.

You say 'Congratulations' to someone in order to congratulate them on something nice that has happened to them or something good that they have done.\nIf you offer someone your congratulations, you congratulate them on something nice that has happened to them or on something good that they have done.\n

In English, there are co-ordinating conjunctions such as 'and' and 'but', and subordinating conjunctions such as 'although', 'because', and 'when'.\n
I can't conk off.\n

A connection is a relationship between two things, people, or groups.
A connection is a joint where two wires or pipes are joined together.
If a place has good road, rail, or air connections, many places can be directly reached from there by car, train, or plane.
If you get a connection at a station or airport, you catch a train, bus, or plane, after getting off another train, bus, or plane, in order to continue your journey.
Your connections are the people who you know or are related to, especially when they are in a position to help you.
If you write or talk to someone in connection with something, you write or talk to them about that thing.
A consonant is a sound such as 'p', 'f', 'n', or 't' which you pronounce by stopping the air flowing freely through your mouth. Compare vowel.\n
The constitution of a country or organization is the system of laws which formally states people's rights and duties.\nYour constitution is your health.\n

If a way of doing something is convenient, it is easy, or very useful or suitable for a particular purpose.
If you describe a place as convenient, you are pleased because it is near to where you are, or because you can reach another place from there quickly and easily.
A convenient time to do something, for example to meet someone, is a time when you are free to do it or would like to do it.
If you describe someone's attitudes or actions as convenient, you think they are only adopting those attitudes or performing those actions in order to avoid something difficult or unpleasant.

persuade / convince
If someone or something convinces you of something, they make you believe that it is true or that it exists.
If someone or something convinces you to do something, they persuade you to do it.
There's still a few I have to convince.

When you cook a meal, you prepare food for eating by heating it.
When you cook food, or when food cooks, it is heated until it is ready to be eaten.
A cook is a person whose job is to prepare and cook food, especially in someone's home or in an institution.
If you say that someone is a good cook, you mean they are good at preparing and cooking food.
If you say that someone has cooked the books, you mean that they have changed figures or a written record in order to deceive people.
"But no cooks or servants," said Annie.
A : I don't want to work here with getting same pay every year. I don't even get any other chances to climb the corporate ladder.\n

voca.word: cost an arm and a leg

expensive / costly / overpriced / pricey / dear
If you say that something is costly, you mean that it costs a lot of money, often more than you would want to pay.
If you describe someone's action or mistake as costly, you mean that it results in a serious disadvantage for them, for example the loss of a large amount of money or the loss of their reputation.

voca.means_ko: [커s듐]\n(특정 지역이나 시대의) 의상, 복장\n(영극, 영화 등에서) 의상, 분장, 변장
voca.means_en:
An actor's or performer's costume is the set of clothes they wear while they are performing.
The clothes worn by people at a particular time in history, or in a particular country, are referred to as a particular type of costume.
A costume play or drama is one which is set in the past and in which the actors wear the type of clothes that were worn in that period.

When you cough, you force air out of your throat with a sudden, harsh noise. You often cough when you are ill, or when you are nervous or want to attract someone's attention.
If you cough blood or mucus, it comes up out of your throat or mouth when you cough.
A cough is an illness in which you cough often and your chest or throat hurts.
When his head bobbed up above the water, he choked and coughed.
B : And the cough has gotten deeper.
Someone's or something's counterpart is another person or thing that has a similar function or position in a different place.\n

voca.means_en:
course / program
Course is often used in the expression 'of course', or instead of 'of course' in informal spoken English. See of course.
The course of a vehicle, especially a ship or aircraft, is the route along which it is travelling.
A course of action is an action or a series of actions that you can do in a particular situation.
You can refer to the way that events develop as, for example, the course of history or the course of events.
A course of medical treatment is a series of treatments that a doctor gives someone.
In sport, a course is an area of land where races are held or golf is played, or the land over which a race takes place.
The course of a river is the channel along which it flows.
If something happens in the course of a particular period of time, it happens during that period of time.
If you are on course for something, you are likely to achieve it.
Your cousin is the child of your uncle or aunt.\nMorgan and Merlin do not even know I have it. A forest sprite, a cousin of my mother's, gave it to me, in case I was ever in urgent need.\n

A house or room that is cosy is comfortable and warm.
If you are cosy, you are comfortable and warm.
You use cosy to describe activities that are pleasant and friendly, and involve people who know each other well.
It's not very cozy today. / I felt cozy sitting by the fire.
This one looked cozy and safe and worm.

If someone or something cramps your style, their presence or existence restricts your behaviour in some way.
They have to warm up before they go into the water. If not, they can get cramps or even a heart attack.

You can refer to any living thing that is not a plant as a creature, especially when it is of an unknown or unfamiliar kind. People also refer to imaginary animals and beings as creatures.
If you say that someone is a particular type of creature, you are focusing on a particular quality they have.
A giant, slimy, mud-colored creature crawled out throught on of the doorways.
"He's a terrifying creature who comes from the Otherwordl," said Teddy.
Instead, perched on the ledge of the nursery window was a horrifying creature.

Someone's credentials are their previous achievements, training, and general background, which indicate that they are qualified to do something.\nSomeone's credentials are a letter or certificate that proves their identity or qualifications.\n
A creditable performance or achievement is of a reasonably high standard.\nIf you describe someone's actions or aims as creditable, you mean that they are morally good.\n

A crest is a design that is the symbol of a noble family, a town, or an organization.

voca.means_en:
angry / mad / indignant / cross / irate
If you cross something such as a room, a road, or an area of land or water, you move or travel to the other side of it. If you cross to a place, you move or travel over a room, road, or area of land or water in order to reach that place.
A road, railway, or bridge that crosses an area of land or water passes over it.
Lines or roads that cross meet and go across each other.
If someone or something crosses a limit or boundary, for example the limit of acceptable behaviour, they go beyond it.
A cross is a shape that consists of a vertical line or piece with a shorter horizontal line or piece across it. It is the most important Christian symbol.

A crow is a large black bird which makes a loud, harsh noise.
When a cock crows, it makes a loud sound, often early in the morning.
If you say that someone is crowing about something they have achieved or are pleased about, you disapprove of them because they keep telling people proudly about it.
Roosters crowed.

voca.means_en:
A crown is a circular ornament, usually made of gold and jewels, which a king or queen wears on their head at official ceremonies. You can also use crown to refer to anything circular that is worn on someone's head.
The government of a country that has a king or queen is sometimes referred to as the Crown. In British criminal cases the prosecutor is the Crown.
Your crown is the top part of your head, at the back.

급행, 속달편, 명확한, 신속한, 급행으로
voca.means_en:
When you express an idea or feeling, or express yourself, you show what you think or feel.
If an idea or feeling expresses itself in some way, it can be clearly seen in someone's actions or in its effects on a situation.
In mathematics, if you express a quantity or mathematical problem in a particular way, you write it using particular symbols, figures, or equations.
An express command or order is one that is clearly and deliberately stated.
If you refer to an express intention or purpose, you are emphasizing that it is a deliberate and specific one that you have before you do something.

voca.means_ko:
[익st뤡-t]
발췌, 추출물,
(화학적 과정등을 거처) 뽑다/얻다, 추출하다

voca.means_en:
To extract a substance means to obtain it from something else, for example by using industrial or chemical processes.
If you extract something from a place, you take it out or pull it out.
When a dentist extracts a tooth, they remove it from the patient's mouth.
If you say that someone extracts something, you disapprove of them because they take it for themselves to gain an advantage.
An extract from a book or piece of writing is a small part of it that is printed or published separately.
An extract is a substance that has been obtained from something else, for example by means of a chemical or industrial process.

voca.means_ko: [아이]\n(한쪽) 눈, 안구, 시력, 눈매, 눈길\n쳐다보다, 눈여겨 보다, 관찰하다
voca.means_en:
Your eyes are the parts of your body with which you see.
You use eye when you are talking about a person's ability to judge things or about the way in which they are considering or dealing with things.
An eye on a potato is one of the dark spots from which new stems grow.
An eye is a small metal loop which a hook fits into, as a fastening on a piece of clothing.

quite / fairly / rather / pretty
Fairly means to quite a large degree. For example, if you say that something is fairly old, you mean that it is old but not very old.
You use fairly instead of 'very' to add emphasis to an adjective or adverb without making it sound too forceful.
A fairy tale is a story for children involving magical events and imaginary creatures.\nThe origin story of Korea's founding is a fun fairy tale.\n
It fell silently into a heap at Jack and Annie's feet.\n
She clutched the mammoth's ears to keep from falling off.\n
We don't want to fall over in these suits.\nA hush fell over the room.\n

voca.means_ko:
[풰^밀뤼어r]
익숙한, 친숙한, 낮익은
~을 아주 잘 아는, ~에 익숙한
(때론 불쾌감을 줄 정도로) 스스럼없는
voca.means_en:
If someone or something is familiar to you, you recognize them or know them well.
If you are familiar with something, you know or understand it well.
If someone you do not know well behaves in a familiar way towards you, they treat you very informally in a way that you might find offensive.

Koreans are very familiar with Japanese food.
I am very familiar with this neighborhood.
We are very familiar with that brand.

voca.means_ko:
[퐈아r]
멀리, (~만큼) 떨어져 (멀리), 
(현재로부터) 오래전에, (특정 시기가) 한참 지나도록, 
훨씬, 아주, 대단히, 
(일의 진척 상황과 관련하여) ~까지, 
훨씬 전의, 먼쪽의, 오래 전에,
voca.means_en:
If one place, thing, or person is far away from another, there is a great distance between them.
If you ask how far a place is, you are asking what distance it is from you or from another place. If you ask how far someone went, you are asking what distance they travelled, or what place they reached.
A time or event that is far away in the future or the past is a long time from the present or from a particular point in time.
You can talk about how far someone or something gets to describe the progress that they make.
You can use far to mean 'very much' when you are comparing two things and emphasizing the difference between them. For example, you can say that something is far better or far worse than something else to indicate that it is very much better or worse. You can also say that something is, for example, far too big to indicate that it is very much too big.
When there are two things of the same kind in a place, the far one is the one that is a greater distance from you.

A fare is the money that you pay for a journey that you make, for example, in a bus, train, or taxi.
If you say that someone or something fares well or badly, you are referring to the degree of success they achieve in a particular situation or activity.
What's the fare to the Opera House?

farther / further / farthest / furthest
Farther is a comparative form of far.
She pointed at a painting farther down the wall.
Without talking, they pushed steadily through the trees and bushes, moving farther and farther from the keepers' cave.
A fatal action has very undesirable effects.\nA fatal accident or illness causes someone's death.\n

voca.means_ko: [^쀄잇t]\n운명(운명에 따라 일어나는, 특히 좋지 않은 일)\n(초월적인 힘으로서의) 운명/숙명
voca.means_en:
luck / chance / coincidence / accident / fortune / fate / destiny / providence
Fate is a power that some people believe controls and decides everything that happens, in a way that cannot be prevented or changed. You can also refer to the fates.
A person's or thing's fate is what happens to them.
If something seals a person's or thing's fate, it makes it certain that they will fail or that something unpleasant will happen to them.
"Then you choose your fate," said the Christmas Knight.
Arthur sat down in his chair and thought about his fate.

voca.means_ko: [퓌어r]\n두려움, 공포, 불안, 근심, 걱정, 염려\n두려워하다, 무서워하다
voca.means_en:
fear / alarm / apprehension / fright / foreboding
Fear is the unpleasant feeling you have when you think that you are in danger.
A fear is a thought that something unpleasant might happen or might have happened.
If you say that there is a fear that something unpleasant or undesirable will happen, you mean that you think it is possible or likely
If you have fears for someone or something, you are very worried because you think that they might be in danger.
If you fear something unpleasant or undesirable, you are worried that it might happen or might have happened.
If you fear for someone or something, you are very worried because you think that they might be in danger
He feared that once they were alone, Squanto would figure out they'd never met before.
His fears slipped away.

voca.means_ko: [퓌-st]\n연회, 잔치, 축제, 향연, (종교적인) 제례, 성찬\n대접받다, 즐기다, 성찬으로 대접하다
voca.means_en:
A feast is a large and special meal.
A feast is a day or time of the year when a special religious celebration takes place.
If you feast on a particular food, you eat a large amount of it with great enjoyment.
If you feast, you take part in a feast.
The title said A Feast to Remember.
He pictured a beautiful, glowing castle lit with candles and filled with knights and ladies feasting and singing.
"It's the great hall," he said "where they have feasts and stuff."

A bird's feathers are the soft covering on its body. Each feather consists of a lot of smooth hairs on each side of a thin stiff centre.
Its feathers glistened in the golden afternoon light.
One of its tail feathers was bent.
Moonlight shone on its sleek blue-black wings, its shaggy throat feathers, its thick neck and big beak.

voca.means_ko:
[^쀠-쳐r]
특징, 기능, 특집기사
이목구비(의 각 부분)
특별히 포함하다, 특징으로 삼다
~의 특징을 이루다
voca.means_en:
A feature of something is an interesting or important part or characteristic of it.
Your features are your eyes, nose, mouth, and other parts of your face.
A feature is a special article in a newspaper or magazine, or a special programme on radio or television.
A feature or a feature film or movie is a full-length film about a fictional situation, as opposed to a short film or a documentary.
A geographical feature is something noticeable in a particular area of country, for example a hill, river, or valley.
When something such as a film or exhibition features a particular person or thing, they are an important part of it.
If someone or something features in something such as a show, exhibition, or magazine, they are an important part of it.
Today's choices featured a mystery meat covered in gravy.
However, I am willing to endure it. It's the price to pay to feel confident when I smile.\n

I felt refreshed when I got home.
It's hard to feel refreshed in this weather.
You will feel refreshed if you get plenty of sleep.
Feet is the plural of foot.\nIt fell silently into a heap at Jack and Annie's feet.\n

A fierce animal or person is very aggressive or angry.
Fierce feelings or actions are very intense or enthusiastic, or involve great activity.
Fierce conditions are very intense, great, or strong.
He knew that the samurai were fierce Japanese fighters.
The samurai were fierce Japanese fighers.
These bears were larger and fiercer than toay's grizzlies.

voca.means_ko:
[퓌겨r]
(특히 공식적인 자료로 제시되는) 수치
모습, 인물, 모양, 숫자, 계산
계산하다, 생각하다, 판단하다, 
(어떤 과정/상황 등에서) 중요하다
voca.means_en:
A figure is a particular amount expressed as a number, especially a statistic.
A figure is any of the ten written symbols from 0 to 9 that are used to represent a number.
You refer to someone that you can see as a figure when you cannot see them clearly or when you are describing them.
In art, a figure is a person in a drawing or a painting, or a statue of a person.
Someone who is referred to as a figure of a particular kind is a person who is well-known and important in some way.
If you figure that something is the case, you think or guess that it is the case.
If you say 'That figures' or 'It figures', you mean that the fact referred to is not surprising.
to calculate the total amount of something\nHe feared that once they were alone, Squanto would figure out they'd never met before.\n

voca.means_ko: (~가 잠깐 자리를 비운 사이에) 대신 일을 봐주다
voca.means_en: to take somebody's place for a short time and do the work they normally do\nCan you fill in for me Wednesday through Friday?\n

to become larger, rounder or fatter
Please fill out this application and give it to me when you're finished.
Please fill out this arrival (landing) card.
I filled out my application.

if a container or a place fills up or somebody fills it up, it becomes completely full
to fill your vehicle with petrol/gas, etc.
Mr. Franklin: Oh I'm sorry Martha but that class is filled up.

A fish's fins are the flat objects which stick out of its body and help it to swim and keep its balance.\nA fin on something such as an aeroplane, rocket, or bomb is a flat part which sticks out and which is intended to help control its movement.\n

In a series of events, things, or people, the final one is the last one.
Final means happening at the end of an event or series of events.
If a decision or someone's authority is final, it cannot be changed or questioned.
The final is the last game or contest in a series and decides who is the winner.

voca.means_ko: (조사하여) 발견하다, 생각해 내다, (해답을) 얻어내다\n~임을 알아내다, 발견하다, \n~에 대한 진상을 알아내다.
voca.means_en: to learn a fact, a piece of information, or the truth about something/somebody\n"But we'll soon find out!" she started waving.\n
used to tell somebody to begin asking questions or to begin to speak\nJohn: Fire away. What's on your mind?\n

A : You must be very excited today.
B : Yes, I am. I couldn't sleep last night.
A : So the soccer game is today at 8:00?
B : Yes. 8:00 sharp.
A : You might be all fired up about this game.

voca.means_ko:
[풔-r엄]
회사, 기업, 업체
굳은, 단단한, 확고한
단단히, 굳게, 견고히

voca.means_en:
A firm is an organization which sells or produces something or which provides a service which people pay for.
If something is firm, it does not change much in shape when it is pressed but is not completely hard.
If something is firm, it does not shake or move when you put weight or pressure on it, because it is strongly made or securely fastened.
If someone's grip is firm or if they perform a physical action in a firm way, they do it with quite a lot of force or pressure but also in a controlled way.
The holiday marks the formation of Korean's first state.\n

voca.means_ko:
[퓟t]
(모양, 크기가 어떤 사람, 사물에) 맞다, 적합하다, 
(옷을) 가봉하다, 설치/설비하다,

적합, 맞는 것(물건), 발작, 경련
꼭맞는, 어울리는, 건강한
voca.means_en:
If something fits, it is the right size and shape to go onto a person's body or onto a particular object.
If you are fitted for a particular piece of clothing, you try it on so that the person who is making it can see where it needs to be altered.
If something fits somewhere, it can be put there or is designed to be put there.
If you fit something into a particular space or place, you put it there.
If you fit something somewhere, you attach it there, or put it there carefully and securely.
If something fits something else or fits into it, it goes together well with that thing or is able to be part of it.
If something is fit for a particular purpose, it is suitable for that purpose.
If someone is fit to do something, they have the appropriate qualities or skills that will allow them to do it.

to find a place for somebody/something, especially when there is not much space
to manage to find time to see somebody or to do something
I'll try and fit you in after lunch.

voca.means_ko:
[^플레시]
(잠깐) 비치다, 번쩍이다, 비추다, 
(불빛으로) 신호를 보내다, 비추다
휙 내보이다, 휙 움직이다/지나가다
(생각이) 불현듯 들다
폭발하다, 번득이다
번쩍임, 섬광, 순간, (잠깐) 반짝임
불빛신호,
voca.means_en:
A flash is a sudden burst of light or of something shiny or bright.
You talk about a flash of something when you are saying that it happens very suddenly and unexpectedly.
Flash is the use of special bulbs to give more light when taking a photograph.
A flash is the same as a flashlight.
If a light flashes or if you flash a light, it shines with a sudden bright light, especially as quick, regular flashes of light.
If something flashes past or by, it moves past you so fast that you cannot see it properly.
If something flashes through or into your mind, you suddenly think about it.
If you flash something such as an identity card, you show it to people quickly and then put it away again.
If a picture or message flashes up on a screen, or if you flash it onto a screen, it is displayed there briefly or suddenly, and often repeatedly.
If you flash news or information to a place, you send it there quickly by computer, satellite, or other system.
If you flash a look or a smile at someone, you suddenly look at them or smile at them.
If someone's eyes flash, they suddenly show a strong emotion, especially anger.
If you describe something as flash, you mean that it looks expensive, fashionable, and new.

voca.means_ko:
[플^뤠러r]
아첨하다, 알랑거리다
자기가 잘난 줄 착각하다
(실제보다) 돋보이게 하다
voca.means_en:
If someone flatters you, they praise you in an exaggerated way that is not sincere, because they want to please you or to persuade you to do something.
If you flatter yourself that something good is the case, you believe that it is true, although others may disagree. If someone says to you 'you're flattering yourself' or 'don't flatter yourself', they mean that they disagree with your good opinion of yourself.
If something flatters you, it makes you appear more attractive.

voca.means_ko: [^플롸-]\n흠이 생기게 하다, 손상하다\n결점, 흠, 결함, 금, 균열
voca.means_en:
A flaw in something such as a theory or argument is a mistake in it, which causes it to be less effective or valid.
A flaw in someone's character is an undesirable quality that they have.
A flaw in something such as a pattern or material is a fault in it that should not be there.

voca.means_ko:
[플레쉬]
(사람, 동물의) 살, 고기, 
(사람의) 피부, 
(정신, 영혼에 대비되는) 육체
voca.means_en:
Flesh is the soft part of a person's or animal's body between the bones and the skin.
You can use flesh to refer to human skin and the human body, especially when you are considering it in a sexual way.
The flesh of a fruit or vegetable is the soft inside part of it.
You use flesh and blood to emphasize that someone has human feelings or weaknesses, often when contrasting them with machines.
If you say that someone is your own flesh and blood, you are emphasizing that they are a member of your family.
If something makes your flesh creep or makes your flesh crawl, it makes you feel disgusted, shocked or frightened.
flick the dust off one's hat\n

voca.means_ko:
[^플릡]
홱 뒤집다, 획 젓히다/젓혀지다, 휙휙 넘기다
(기계의 버튼 등을) 탁 누르다, 돌리다
(너무 화가나거나 흥분하여) 확 돌아버리다
(손가락으로)툭/톡 던지다, ~을 튀기다,
툭 던지기, 공중제비, 재주넘기, (책장을) 휙휙 넘겨봄
voca.means_en:
If you flip a device on or off, or if you flip a switch, you turn it on or off by pressing the switch quickly.
If you flip through the pages of a book, for example, you quickly turn over the pages in order to find a particular one or to get an idea of the contents.
If something flips over, or if you flip it over or into a different position, it moves or is moved into a different position.
If you flip something, especially a coin, you use your thumb to make it turn over and over, as it goes through the air.
If you say that someone is being flip, you disapprove of them because you think that what they are saying shows they are not being serious enough about something.
Francine dodged left and flipped the carton past Arthur's hand.

voca.means_ko:
[플로우t]
(물 위나 공중에서) 떠 가다, 흘러가다, 
(가라앉지 않고 물에) 뜨다, (액체 위에) 띄우다
떠오르다, 떠다니다
미끄러지듯 걷다/움직이다
voca.means_en:
If something or someone is floating in a liquid, they are in the liquid, on or just below the surface, and are being supported by it. You can also float something on a liquid.
Something that floats lies on or just below the surface of a liquid when it is put in it and does not sink.
Something that floats in or through the air hangs in it or moves slowly and gently through it.
If you float a project, plan, or idea, you suggest it for others to think about.
If a company director floats their company, they start to sell shares in it to the public.
If a government floats its country's currency or allows it to float, it allows the currency's value to change freely in relation to other currencies.
Sounds of music and laughter floated on the breeze.
Annie's braids floated on the wind.

She's fluent in Polish.
By the age of 17, he was fluent in five different languages
Do you think you are fluent in English?

voca.means_ko:
[^플롸더r]
(빠르고 가볍게) 흔들다, 펄럭이다, 
(새, 곤충이 날개를) 파닥이다, 날개치다, 두근거리다
펄럭임, 날개짓, 두근거림, 흥분, 혼란
voca.means_en:
If something thin or light flutters, or if you flutter it, it moves up and down or from side to side with a lot of quick, light movements.
If something light such as a small bird or a piece of paper flutters somewhere, it moves through the air with small quick movements.
If you have a flutter, you have a small bet on something such as a horse race.
A huge yellow leaf fluttered through the open window and came to rest at Jack's feet.
Rok fluttered his long black wings.
She fluttered to the window ledge and perched with Teddy.
When it is foggy, there is fog.\nIf you say that you haven't the foggiest or you haven't the foggiest idea, you are emphasizing that you do not know something.\n

Foil consists of sheets of metal as thin as paper. It is used to wrap food in.
If you refer to one thing or person as a foil for another, you approve of the fact that they contrast with each other and go well together, often in a way that makes the second thing or person seem better or less harmful.
If you foil someone's plan or attempt to do something, for example to commit a crime, you succeed in stopping them from doing what they want.

Food is what people and animals eat.
If you are off your food, you do not want to eat, usually because you are ill.
If you give someone food for thought, you make them think carefully about something.
If you get food poisoning, you become ill because you have eaten food that has gone bad.\n

voca.means_ko: (할 일을 안하고) 노닥거리다, \n시간을 낭비하다, 가지고 놀다, 바보짓을 하다
voca.means_en:
to waste time or behave in a silly way
to have a sexual relationship with another person's partner or with somebody who is not your partner
if two people fool around, they kiss and touch each other in a sexual way

If someone's behaviour or action is foolish, it is not sensible and shows a lack of good judgment.\nIf you look or feel foolish, you look or feel so silly or ridiculous that people are likely to laugh at you.\n
Laura: You told Shelly that you weren't going to get married for a long time.\nThey've been married for a long time.\n

I had to got to the emergency room. I had to get my foot stitched up. It was hard to walk properly for a while.\nA : You've already been studying for hours and hours. I think it would be good for you to take a break for a while.\n
in order to help somebody/something or because you like somebody/something\n"but we must get it back! For the sake of Camelot's future!"\n

voca.means_ko: 잊어버려 (중요하지 않으니 걱정하지 말라는 뜻)\n생각도 하지마,\n그만 지껄여
voca.means_en:
used to tell somebody that something is not important and that they should not worry about it
used to tell somebody that you are not going to repeat what you said
used to emphasize that you are saying ‘no' to something
used to tell somebody to stop talking about something because they are annoying you

If you forgive someone who has done something bad or wrong, you stop being angry with them and no longer want to punish them.
If you say that someone could be forgiven for doing something, you mean that they were wrong or mistaken, but not seriously, because many people would have done the same thing in those circumstances.
Forgive is used in polite expressions and apologies like 'forgive me' and 'forgive my ignorance' when you are saying or doing something that might seem rude, silly, or complicated.
If an organization such as a bank forgives someone's debt, they agree not to ask for that money to be repaid.

voca.means_ko: [^포r-칀]\n(특히 사람의 삶에 영향을 미치는) 운/행운\n재산, 부, 거금,
voca.means_en:
luck / chance / coincidence / accident / fortune / fate / destiny / providence
You can refer to a large sum of money as a fortune or a small fortune to emphasize how large it is.
Someone who has a fortune has a very large amount of money.
Fortune or good fortune is good luck. Ill fortune is bad luck.
If you talk about someone's fortunes or the fortunes of something, you are talking about the extent to which they are doing well or being successful.
As long as the family kept the diamond safe, they would have good fortune.
Freckles are small light brown spots on someone's skin, especially on their face.\nHe had a friendly, freckled face and dark, twinkly eye.\n

If you refer to someone as a freeloader, you disapprove of them because they take advantage of other people's kindness, for example by accepting food or accommodation from them, without giving anything in return.\n

fear / alarm / apprehension / fright / foreboding
Fright is a sudden feeling of fear, especially the fear that you feel when something unpleasant surprises you.
A fright is an experience which makes you suddenly afraid.
If a person or animal takes fright at something, they are suddenly frightened by it, and want to run away or to stop doing what they are doing.
He couldn't tell if it was from cold or from fright.
From now on, don't let it happen again.\nC : Let me take a look. It's clogged from all the hair getting stuck in the drain. Please use a drain net from now on.\n

If the weather is frosty, the temperature is below freezing.
You describe the ground or an object as frosty when it is covered with frost.
Puffs of frosty air blew from the stag's nostrils.

Fruit or a fruit is something which grows on a tree or bush and which contains seeds or a stone covered by a substance that you can eat.
The fruits or the fruit of someone's work or activity are the good things that result from it.
If a plant fruits, it produces fruit.
If the effort that you put into something or a particular way of doing something bears fruit, it is successful and produces good results.
The first fruits or the first fruit of a project or activity are its earliest results or profits.

Fuel is a substance such as coal, oil, or petrol that is burned to provide heat or power.
To fuel a situation means to make it become worse or more intense.
The keepers' blue flames grew weaker and weaker, as if they were running out of fuel.

Funeral arrangements have not been finalized.
People wore deep mourning at Tom's funeral.
Offer an even number of flowers if you go to a funeral.

voca.means_ko:
더 먼, 그 이상의
(거리상으로) 더 멀리, 더욱 더, 
뿐만 아니라, 게다가
더 이상의, 추가의
voca.means_en:
farther / further / farthest / furthest
Further means to a greater extent or degree.
If you go or get further with something, or take something further, you make some progress.
If someone goes further in a discussion, they make a more extreme statement or deal with a point more thoroughly.
Further means a greater distance than before or than something else.
Further is used in expressions such as 'further back' and 'further ahead' to refer to a point in time that is earlier or later than the time you are talking about.

The future is the period of time that will come after the present, or the things that will happen then.
Someone's future, or the future of something, is what will happen to them or what they will do after the present time.
If you say that someone or something has a future, you mean that they are likely to be successful or to survive.
When people trade in futures, they buy stocks and shares, commodities such as coffee or oil, or foreign currency at a price that is agreed at the time of purchase for items which are delivered some time in the future.
Future things will happen or exist after the present time.
In grammar, the future tense of a verb is the one used to talk about things that are going to happen. In English, this applies to verb groups consisting of 'will' or 'shall' and the base form of a verb. The future perfect tense of a verb is used to talk about things that will have happened at some time in the future.
"The whole future of our kingdom depends upon your success," said Merlin.

voca.means_ko: 쎈 바람, 강풍, 돌풍,  왁자지껄한 웃음
voca.means_en: A gale is a very strong wind.\nYou'll see a gale if I don't get me gold today, by thunder.\n

voca.means_ko: 측정하다, 재다, 평가/판단하다\n표준치수, 규격, 계측기, 게이지
voca.means_en:
If you gauge the speed or strength of something, or if you gauge an amount, you measure or calculate it, often by using a device of some kind.
If you gauge people's actions, feelings, or intentions in a particular situation, you carefully consider and judge them.
A gauge is a device that measures the amount or quantity of something and shows the amount measured.
A gauge of someone's feelings or a situation is a fact or event that can be used to judge them.
A gauge is the distance between the two rails on a railway line.

look / glance / gaze / stare / glimpse / glare
If you gaze at someone or something, you look steadily at them for a long time, for example because you find them attractive or interesting, or because you are thinking about something else.
You can talk about someone's gaze as a way of describing how they are looking at something, especially when they are looking steadily at it.
Jack followed her gaze.
Annie was gazing down the street at the Frog Creek woods.
The three knights gazed in wonder at the white stag.

voca.means_ko: 기어를 넣다, 적응시키다, 준비하다, 맞추다\n기어, 톱니바퀴, 장비, 소지품, 의류, 복장
voca.means_en:
The gears on a machine or vehicle are a device for changing the rate at which energy is changed into motion.
If someone or something is geared to or towards a particular purpose, they are organized or designed in order to achieve that purpose.
Annie ran to get their rain gear.
I pulled out some of my dad's old fishing gear.

A person's gender is the fact that they are male or female.
You can refer to all male people or all female people as a particular gender.
In grammar, the gender of a noun, pronoun, or adjective is whether it is masculine, feminine, or neuter. A word's gender can affect its form and behaviour. In English, only personal pronouns such as 'she', reflexive pronouns such as 'itself', and possessive determiners such as 'his' have gender.

voca.means_ko:
[제너럴]

일반적인, 대체적인, 대략적인
종합적인
장군
voca.means_en:
A general is a high-ranking officer in the armed forces, usually in the army.
If you talk about the general situation somewhere or talk about something in general terms, you are describing the situation as a whole rather than considering its details or exceptions.
You use general to describe several items or activities when there are too many of them or when they are not important enough to mention separately.
You use general to describe something that involves or affects most people, or most people in a particular group.
If you describe something as general, you mean that it is not restricted to any one thing or area.
General is used to describe a person's job, usually as part of their title, to indicate that they have complete responsibility for the administration of an organization or business.

You use generally to give a summary of a situation, activity, or idea without referring to the particular details of it.
You use generally to say that something happens or is used on most occasions but not on every occasion.
Generally, we do use this for women. For men, we say: "Loosen your tie". It's the same idea. "To loosen the tie" means relax, don't be so serious, don't be so stiff. Relax, have fun, do whatever you want. Tomorrow's another day, so let your hair down.

[줴너^뤠이션]
세대, 시대
(특정 활동에 관여하는 비슷한 연령층의) 사람들
(특히 전기, 열 등의) 발생
voca.means_en:
A generation is all the people in a group or country who are of a similar age, especially when they are considered as having the same experiences or attitudes.
A generation is the period of time, usually considered to be about thirty years, that it takes for children to grow up and become adults and have children of their own.
You can use generation to refer to a stage of development in the design and manufacture of machines or equipment.
Generation is also the production of a form of energy or power from fuel or another source of power such as water.
Generation is used to indicate how long members of your family have had a particular nationality. For example, second generation means that you were born in the country you live in, but your parents were not.

voca.means_ko: [^죄너러s]\n(무엇을 주는 데 있어서) 후한, 너그러운\n넉넉한, 관대한, 아량있는
voca.means_en:
A generous person gives more of something, especially money, than is usual or expected.
A generous person is friendly, helpful, and willing to see the good qualities in someone or something.
A generous amount of something is much larger than is usual or necessary.
You use genetic to describe something that is concerned with genetics or with genes.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^젠털]
온화한, 순한, 점잖은, 친절한, 심하지 않은
길들이다, 달래다

voca.means_en:
Someone who is gentle is kind, mild, and calm.
Gentle actions or movements are performed in a calm and controlled manner, with little force.
If you describe the weather, especially the wind, as gentle, you mean it is pleasant and calm and not harsh or violent.
A gentle slope or curve is not steep or severe.
A gentle heat is a fairly low heat.
A gentle wind brushed against his skin.

Geography is the study of the countries of the world and of such things as the land, seas, climate, towns, and population.\nThe geography of a place is the way that features such as rivers, mountains, towns, or streets are arranged within it.\n

Geometry is the branch of mathematics concerned with the properties and relationships of lines, angles, curves, and shapes.\nThe geometry of an object is its shape or the relationship of its parts to each other.\n
a line or surface within or on the earth connecting points of equal temperature\nthe representation of such a line or surface on a map or diagram\n
of or relating to the heat in the interior of the earth\n
A germ is a very small organism that causes disease.\nThe germ of something such as an idea is something which developed or might develop into that thing.\n
A gerund is a noun formed from a verb which refers to an action, process, or state. In English, gerunds end in '-ing', for example 'running' and 'thinking'.\n

이해하다
voca.means_en:
become / get / go / turn
You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
Get is used with expressions referring to states or situations. For example, to get into trouble means to start being in trouble.
To get someone or something into a particular state or situation means to cause them to be in it.
If you get someone to do something, you cause them to do it by asking, persuading, or telling them to do it.
If you get something done, you cause it to be done.
To get somewhere means to move there.
When you get to a place, you arrive there.
To get something or someone into a place or position means to cause them to move there.
If you get to do something, you eventually or gradually reach a stage at which you do it.
If you get to do something, you manage to do it or have the opportunity to do it.
You can use get in expressions like get moving, get going, and get working when you want to tell people to begin moving, going, or working quickly.
If you get to a particular stage in your life or in something you are doing, you reach that stage.
You can use get to talk about the progress that you are making. For example, if you say that you are getting somewhere, you mean that you are making progress, and if you say that something won't get you anywhere, you mean it will not help you to progress at all.
I have to get them to come to me! Jack thought frantically.

I got a bad cut
If you're not careful, you might get a bad cut.
She got a bad cut on her hand.

voca.means_ko: 출세하다, 성공하다\n돈을 왕창 벌다, 빚을 청산하다\n(~를) 앞서다
voca.means_en: He told me he quit because he couldn't get ahead.\n

voca.word: get all bent out of shape
voca.means_en: My father got all bent out of shape when I scratched his car.\nMatt: He got all bent out of shape.\n

to make an escape; leave
to make a start
to succeed in leaving a place
to escape from somebody or a place
an exclamation indicating mild disbelief
I know but I promised my wife that we'd get away this weekend

People can get cramps if they don't warm up.
It's very scary to get cramps in water.
I always get cramps when I go for a run.

Dental braces get in the way when I eat.
Please put it where it won't get in the way.
I tried to move, but something got in the way.
make a woman who is not married pregnant\nNext parents must always keep an eye on their children. Otherwise, kids may get into trouble.\n

voca.means_ko: 내리다, 제거하다, 이륙하다, ~을 우송하다, 부치다\n(직장에서) 퇴근하다

to leave a place or start a journey
(with something) to escape or nearly escape punishment
(with something) to escape or nearly escape injury in an accident
Well, you may not know this, but because it's the last day of 2014, everybody gets off work early today so that they can go back home early.
I had sprained my ankle. The swelling was bad. I couldn't get on my feet.\n
annoy somebody a lot\nB : You're really getting on my nerves!\n
Can I talk to you for a minute? I want to get something off my chest.\nMatt: I told him I had to get something off my chest.\n

I had to get my foot stitched up.
He hurt his hand, but thankfully he didn't need to get it stitched up.
The cut was deep, and I had to get it stitched up.

Food gets stuck in my dental braces.
His hand got stuck in the hole.
The car got stuck in the mud.
C : Let me take a look. It's clogged from all the hair getting stuck in the drain. Please use a drain net from now on.

voca.means_en:
I hope so. You are hard to get through to sometimes.
I thought I got through to her, but I guess I didn't.
I have trouble getting through to my husband sometimes.
Norma: I don't know how to get through to you!
It's sometimes difficult getting through to children.

to meet with somebody for social purposes or to discuss or organize something
to begin a relationship with somebody
Let's get together and have lunch some day.
Yes. My brother's friends get together every Thursday at his house.
Ellen: A few of us are getting together for lunch. Do you want to come?
We should get together for lunch next week.

Record yourself speaking English. Listening to yourself can be strange at first but you get used to it.
It's only been a few days. You will get used to it.
She would have to get used to a new desk and a new classroom.

voca.means_en: A ghoul is an imaginary evil spirit. Ghouls are said to steal bodies from graves and eat them.\n"I'm going to go put on my ghoul makeup now."\n

A girl is a female child.
You can refer to someone's daughter as a girl.
Young women are often referred to as girls. This use could cause offence.
Some people refer to a man's girlfriend as his girl.

You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
You use give to say that a person does something for another person. For example, if you give someone a lift, you take them somewhere in your car.

allow somebody/something to go first
feel and express a strong emotion, without trying to hide it or stop it
allow somebody to have what they want
Then Jack's knees gave way, and he sank to the ground.

to stop trying to do something, usually because it is too difficult
The tiger soon became hungry and gave up. However, the bear kept at it.
Mother: The point is you will get a job if you don't give up.
I looked everywhere for my keys but I finally gave up.
Someone who is gleeful is happy and excited, often because of someone else's bad luck.\n

Glory is the fame and admiration that you gain by doing something impressive.
A person's glories are the occasions when they have done something people greatly admire which makes them famous.
The glory of something is its great beauty or impressive nature.
The glories of a culture or place are the things that people admire most about it.
If you glory in a situation or activity, you enjoy it very much.
If you go out in a blaze of glory, you do something very dramatic at the end of your career or your life which makes you famous.

voca.means_en:
shine / gleam / glow / sparkle / glisten / shimmer / glitter / twinkle / glint
A glow is a dull, steady light, for example the light produced by a fire when there are no flames.
A glow is a pink colour on a person's face, usually because they are healthy or have been exercising.
If you feel a glow of satisfaction or achievement, you have a strong feeling of pleasure because of something that you have done or that has happened.
If something glows, it produces a dull, steady light.
On the floor the letter M glowed in the dim light.
It was clear and smooth. It almost seemed to glow.
Only this cave seemed to have a golden glow.
Everything was bathed in a golden red glow.
He pictured a beautiful, glowing castle lit with candles and filled with knights and ladies feasting and singing.
It had glowing red eyes and long, curled claws.
In children's stories, a gnome is an imaginary creature that is like a tiny old man with a beard and pointed hat. In Britain people sometimes have small statues of gnomes in their gardens.\n

voca.means_en:
You want to go along with us for the ride?
I can't go along with you on that proposal.

You're just copying word for word, you're not actually doing anything active with the material you're listening to. So, working with a computer-and I've seen this in my university-a lot of students also end up going on Facebook during the lesson or lecture. So, a lot of  the times they get very distracted. When they should be listening, they're actually not.\n
I'm going out with Michael Jackson.\n

to become higher in price, level, etc.; to rise
(to somebody/something) to go towards somebody/something
(to) to travel from one place to another, especially from the south of a country to the north
to be built; to be put up
to be destroyed by fire or an explosion
In a flash, he went up on his knees.
Or there's a girl you really like or a boy you really like, and you go up to this person and you say: "I have to get something off my chest. I've been in love with you for like five years. I can't hold it inside anymore. I have to get it off my chest, so I'm telling you."
Soft drinks go well with pizza.\nWhen I'm having bread or cookies, milk goes well with them.\n

voca.means_en: Gone are the days of movie tickets costing a dollar. Now it's ten dollars.\nSo gone are the days of wearing jeans and t-shirts to work huh?\n

good / goodness
People sometimes say 'goodness' or 'my goodness' to express surprise.
Goodness is the quality of being kind, helpful, and honest.

discussion / conversation / dialogue / talk / consultation / chat / gossip
Gossip is informal conversation, often about other people's private affairs.
If you describe someone as a gossip, you mean that they enjoy talking informally to people about the private affairs of others.
If you gossip with someone, you talk informally, especially about other people or local events. You can also say that two people gossip.

voca.means_en:
If you grab something, you take it or pick it up suddenly and roughly.
If you grab at something, you try to grab it.
If you grab someone who is walking past, you succeed in getting their attention.
If you grab someone's attention, you do something in order to make them notice you.
If you grab something such as food, drink, or sleep, you manage to get some quickly.
If you grab something such as a chance or opportunity, or grab at it, you take advantage of it eagerly.
A grab for something such as power or fame is an attempt to gain it.
He galloped toward them, grabbing his bow.
He leaped up from his chair and tried to grab her.

voca.means_ko: [g뤠이s]\n우아함, 아름다움, 예의, 은혜, 은총\n우아하게 하다, 장식하다
voca.means_en:
If someone moves with grace, they move in a smooth, controlled, and attractive way.
If someone behaves with grace, they behave in a pleasant, polite, and dignified way, even when they are upset or being treated unfairly.
The graces are the ways of behaving and doing things which are considered polite and well-mannered.
Grace is used in expressions such as a day's grace and a month's grace to say that you are allowed that amount of extra time before you have to finish something.
In Christianity and some other religions, grace is the kindness that God shows to people because he loves them.
When someone says grace before or after a meal, they say a prayer in which they thank God for the food and ask Him to bless it.

Someone or something that is graceful moves in a smooth and controlled way which is attractive to watch.
Something that is graceful is attractive because it has a pleasing shape or style.
If a person's behaviour is graceful, it is polite, kind, and pleasant, especially in a difficult situation.

Grammar is the ways that words can be put together in order to make sentences.
Someone's grammar is the way in which they obey or do not obey the rules of grammar when they write or speak.
A grammar is a book that describes the rules of a language.
A particular grammar is a particular theory that is intended to explain the rules of a language.
Grammatical is used to indicate that something relates to grammar.\nIf someone's language is grammatical, it is considered correct because it obeys the rules of grammar.\n

voca.means_en:
hold / hold on / cling / clutch / grip / grasp / clasp / hang on
If you grasp something, you take it in your hand and hold it very firmly.
If you grasp something that is complicated or difficult to understand, you understand it.
A grasp is a very firm hold or grip.
If you say that something is in someone's grasp, you disapprove of the fact that they possess or control it. If something slips from your grasp, you lose it or lose control of it.
If you say that something is within someone's grasp, you mean that it is very likely that they will achieve it.
Annie held Jack's right hand as he grasped the slender golden hand of the dancer on his left.

A grate is a framework of metal bars in a fireplace, which holds the coal or wood.
If you grate food such as cheese or carrots, you rub it over a metal tool called a grater so that the food is cut into very small pieces.
When something grates, it rubs against something else making a harsh, unpleasant sound.
If something such as someone's behaviour grates on you or grates, it makes you feel annoyed.

A grave event or situation is very serious, important, and worrying.
A grave person is quiet and serious in their appearance or behaviour.

If something is greeted in a particular way, people react to it in that way.
If you are greeted by something, it is the first thing you notice in a particular place.
We say aloha when we greet our friends. And we say aloha when we leave them.

When you grin, you smile broadly.
A grin is a broad smile.
If you grin and bear it, you accept a difficult or unpleasant situation without complaining because you know there is nothing you can do to make things better. / Cap'n Bones grinned his black-toothed grin.
Cap'n Bones gave Jack a horrible grin. / He seemed to be grinning at them. / The monkey just grinned.
Jack grinned, "Me too" he said.
He grinned a big grin just like his sister's.
He broke into a big grin.
"No! But I should like to!" Teddy said with a grin.
"I don't know," said Teddy. Then he grinned.

hold / hold on / cling / clutch / grip / grasp / clasp / hang on
If you grip something, you take hold of it with your hand and continue to hold it firmly.
If you are gripped by something such as a story or a series of events, your attention is concentrated on it and held by it.
A grip is a firm, strong hold on something.
Someone's grip on something is the power and control they have over it.
If things such as shoes or car tyres have grip, they do not slip.
A grip is a bag that is smaller than a suitcase, and that you use when you are travelling.

He leaped up from his chair and tried to grip her.
Gripping his pencil made Jack feel stronger.
