돌진, 쇄도, 혼잡
아주급한, 시급한
voca.means_en:
If you rush somewhere, you go there quickly.
If people rush to do something, they do it as soon as they can, because they are very eager to do it.
If you rush something, you do it in a hurry, often too quickly and without much care.
If you rush someone or something to a place, you take them there quickly.
A rush is a situation in which you need to go somewhere or do something very quickly.
If there is a rush for something, many people suddenly try to get it or do it.
As they started down the stairs, servants rushed by.
I don't want to rush you but I need you to make it done quickly.

Safety is the state of being safe from harm or danger.
If you reach safety, you reach a place where you are safe from danger.
If you are concerned about the safety of something, you are concerned that it might be harmful or dangerous.
If you are concerned for someone's safety, you are concerned that they might be in danger.
Safety features or measures are intended to make something less dangerous.
If you say that there is safety in numbers, you mean that you are safer doing something if there are a lot of people doing it rather than doing it alone.

If you do something for the sake of something, you do it for that purpose or in order to achieve that result. You can also say that you do it for something's sake.
If you do something for its own sake, you do it because you want to, or because you enjoy it, and not for any other reason. You can also talk about, for example, art for art's sake or sport for sport's sake.
When you do something for someone's sake, you do it in order to help them or make them happy.
Some people use expressions such as for God's sake, for heaven's sake, for goodness sake, or for Pete's sake in order to express annoyance or impatience, or to add force to a question or request. The expressions 'for God's sake' and 'for Christ's sake' could cause offence.
For Morgan's sake!
"but we must get it back! For the sake of Camelot's future!"

The sale of goods is the act of selling them for money.
The sales of a product are the quantity of it that is sold.
The part of a company that deals with sales deals with selling the company's products.
A sale is an occasion when a shop sells things at less than their normal price.
A sale is an event when goods are sold to the person who offers the highest price.

voca.means_ko: [쎄디s풱션]\n만족, 충족\n(불만, 부채, 부상 등에 대한) 배상/보상
voca.means_en:
satisfaction / happiness / contentment / fulfilment / glee
Satisfaction is the pleasure that you feel when you do something or get something that you wanted or needed to do or get.
If you get satisfaction from someone, you get money or an apology from them because you have been treated badly.
If you do something to someone's satisfaction, they are happy with the way that you have done it.

one of the giant planets, the sixth planet from the sun, around which revolve planar concentric rings (Saturn's rings) consisting of small frozen particles. The planet has at least 30 satellites. Mean distance from sun: 1425 million km; period of revolution around sun: 29.41 years; period of axial rotation: 10.23 hours; equatorial diameter and mass: 9.26 and 95.3 times that of the earth, respectively See also Titan\n

A scaly animal has small pieces of hard skin covering its body.
If someone's skin is scaly, it has dry areas and small pieces of it come off.
It was cold and scaly. It wiggled and jerked!

voca.means_ko: [s끼임]\n계획, 기획, 음모, 조직, 설계\n~하려고 꾸미다, 구상/계획하다
voca.means_en:
A scheme is a plan or arrangement involving many people which is made by a government or other organization.
A scheme is someone's plan for achieving something.
If you say that people are scheming, you mean that they are making secret plans in order to gain something for themselves.
Peanut jumped out of Annie's arms and scurried back to the letter M.\n

If you search for something or someone, you look carefully for them.
If you search a place, you look carefully for something or someone there.
If a police officer or someone else in authority searches you, they look carefully to see whether you have something hidden on you.
If you search for information on a computer, you give the computer an instruction to find that information.
A search is an attempt to find something or someone by looking for them carefully.
If you go in search of something or someone, you try to find them.
You say 'search me' when someone asks you a question and you want to emphasize that you do not know the answer.

voca.means_ko:
[쎄큰d]
(순서상으로) 두번째의, 둘째의
보충하다, 조언하다
초, 잠시, 순간
두번째의, 또 하나의
voca.means_en:
A second is one of the sixty parts that a minute is divided into. People often say 'a second' or 'seconds' when they simply mean a very short time.
The second item in a series is the one that you count as number two.
Second is used before superlative adjectives to indicate that there is only one thing better or larger than the thing you are referring to.
You say second when you want to make a second point or give a second reason for something.
If you second a proposal in a meeting or debate, you formally express your agreement with it so that it can then be discussed or voted on.

voca.means_ko:
[씨k륏t]
기밀, 비밀, 비결, 비법, 신비
비밀의, 숨겨진
(행동이) 남몰래 하는, 남이 모르는
voca.means_en:
If something is secret, it is known about by only a small number of people, and is not told or shown to anyone else.
A secret is a fact that is known by only a small number of people, and is not told to anyone else.
If you say that a particular way of doing things is the secret of achieving something, you mean that it is the best or only way to achieve it.
Something's secrets are the things about it which have never been fully explained.
If you do something in secret, you do it without anyone else knowing.
If you say that someone can keep a secret, you mean that they can be trusted not to tell other people a secret that you have told them.
If you make no secret of something, you tell others about it openly and clearly.
This must be the secret castle that guards the Diamond of Destiny!

voca.means_ko:
[씨이]
(눈으로) 보다, (보고) 알다, 목격하다, 보이다
(논의 등을 위해 사람을) 만나다, 보다
알다, 이해하다, 
(~라고) 보다/생각/판단 하다
(~일 것으로) 보다/예상하다
voca.means_en:
see - saw - seen
look / watch / see / view / observe/ regard
When you see something, you notice it using your eyes.
If you see someone, you visit them or meet them.
If you see an entertainment such as a play, film, concert, or sports game, you watch it.
If you see that something is true or exists, you realize by observing it that it is true or exists.
If you see what someone means or see why something happened, you understand what they mean or understand why it happened.
If you see someone or something as a certain thing, you have the opinion that they are that thing.
If you see a particular quality in someone, you believe they have that quality. If you ask what someone sees in a particular person or thing, you want to know what they find attractive about that person or thing.
People say 'I'll see' or 'We'll see' to indicate that they do not intend to make a decision immediately, and will decide later.
People say 'let me see' or 'let's see' when they are trying to remember something, or are trying to find something.
You can say 'you see' when you are explaining something to someone, to encourage them to listen and understand.

voca.means_ko: 직접 확인하다\n자신이 직접 보다, \n(~을) 스스로 확인하다
voca.means_en:
I went to the restaurant to see for myself.
You can't be sure until you see for yourself.
She trusts me, but she wants to see for herself.

voca.means_ko: [씨익k]\n(~을 발견하기 위해) 찾다, 모색하다, 추구하다, 구하다\n~하려고 시도하다
voca.means_en:
If you seek something such as a job or a place to live, you try to find one.
When someone seeks something, they try to obtain it.
If you seek someone's help or advice, you contact them in order to ask for it.
If you seek to do something, you try to do it.

voca.means_ko:
[씨이-z]
와락/꽉 붙잡다, 움켜잡다,
(흔히 폭력을 써서) 장악하다, 점령하다
체포하다, 붙잡다
voca.means_en:
If you seize something, you take hold of it quickly, firmly, and forcefully.
When a group of people seize a place or seize control of it, they take control of it quickly and suddenly, using force.
If a government or other authority seize someone's property, they take it from them, often by force.
When someone is seized, they are arrested or captured.
When you seize an opportunity, you take advantage of it and do something that you want to do.

If someone has a seizure, they have a sudden violent attack of an illness, especially one that affects their heart or brain.
If there is a seizure of power or a seizure of an area of land, a group of people suddenly take control of the place, using force.
When an organization such as the police or customs service makes a seizure of illegal goods, they find them and take them away.
If a financial institution or a government makes a seizure of someone's assets, they take their money or property from them because they have not paid money that they owe.

voca.means_ko: [쎌f]\n(어떤 사람의 평상시) 모습, 본모습, \n자기, 자신, 자아
voca.means_en: Your self is your basic personality or nature, especially considered in terms of what you are really like as a person.\nA person's self is the essential part of their nature which makes them different from everyone and everything else.\n
Yes. I called her this morning and she said she'd send someone over.\n

voca.means_ko: (자신보다 앞서 도착하도록) ~을 미리 보내다\n(어떤 사람의 옛날 주소로 온 편지를 새 주소로) 다시 보내다
voca.means_en:
to send a letter, etc. that has arrived at somebody's old address to their new one
to send something you have received to somebody else for them to see or deal with
to send something to a place so that it arrives before you get there

voca.means_ko:
[^쎈s]
(오감중의 하나인) 감각, 의식, 의미
(어떤 것을 이해, 판단할 줄 아는) 감각
~을 느끼다, 감지하다
voca.means_en:
Your senses are the physical abilities of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste.
If you have a sense that something is the case, you think that it is the case, although you may not have firm, clear evidence for this belief.
If you have a sense of guilt or relief, for example, you feel guilty or relieved.
If you have a sense of something such as duty or justice, you are aware of it and believe it is important.
If you sense something, you become aware of it or you realize it, although it is not very obvious.
Someone who has a sense of timing or style has a natural ability with regard to timing or style. You can also say that someone has a bad sense of timing or style.
I sense he's not here.

voca.means_ko:
[^씨어리어s]
(나쁘거나 위험한 정도가) 심각한, 중대한
진지한, 만만찮은
(양이 많음을 강조하여) 정말 많은
voca.means_en:
serious / grave / earnest / solemn
Serious problems or situations are very bad and cause people to be worried or afraid.
Serious matters are important and deserve careful and thoughtful consideration.
When important matters are dealt with in a serious way, they are given careful and thoughtful consideration.
Serious music or literature requires concentration to understand or appreciate it.
Generally, we do use this for women. For men, we say: "Loosen your tie". It's the same idea. "To loosen the tie" means relax, don't be so serious, don't be so stiff. Relax, have fun, do whatever you want. Tomorrow's another day, so let your hair down.

You use seriously to indicate that you are not joking and that you really mean what you say.
You say 'seriously' when you are surprised by what someone has said, as a way of asking them if they really mean it.
If you take someone or something seriously, you believe that they are important and deserve attention.
"Seriously, what just happened in there?" he asked.
"Seriously?" he whispered.

A servant is someone who is employed to work at another person's home, for example as a cleaner or a gardener.
You can use servant to refer to someone or something that provides a service for people or can be used by them.
"But no cooks or servants," said Annie.
I'm going to set up a meeting with the owners of the two companies.\n

When you sew something such as clothes, you make them or repair them by joining pieces of cloth together by passing thread through them with a needle.\nWhen something such as a hand or finger is sewn back by a doctor, it is joined with the patient's body using a needle and thread.\n

voca.means_ko: 오래 입어서 낡은, 초라한(옷차림), 비천한/비루한\n황폐한, 낡아빠진
voca.means_en:
Shabby things or places look old and in bad condition.
A person who is shabby is wearing old, worn clothes.
If you describe someone's behaviour as shabby, you think they behave in an unfair or unacceptable way.
Not too shabby!

voca.means_ko:
[쉐익k]
흔들리다. 진동하다, 악수하다
(부정, 반대, 의혹 등의 의미로) 고개를 흔들다/젓다
털다, 떨리다
진동, 흔들림
voca.means_en:
shake - shook - shaken
If you shake something, you hold it and move it quickly backwards and forwards or up and down. You can also shake a person, for example, because you are angry with them or because you want them to wake up.
If you shake yourself or your body, you make a lot of quick, small, repeated movements without moving from the place where you are.
If you shake your head, you turn it from side to side in order to say 'no' or to show disbelief or sadness.
If you are shaking, or a part of your body is shaking, you are making quick, small movements that you cannot control, for example because you are cold or afraid.
If you shake your fist or an object such as a stick at someone, you wave it in the air in front of them because you are angry with them.
If you describe a person's action or attitude as shameful, you think that it is so bad that the person ought to be ashamed.\n

A company's shares are the many equal parts into which its ownership is divided. Shares can be bought by people as an investment.
If something is divided or distributed among a number of different people or things, each of them has, or is responsible for, a share of it.
If you share something with another person, you both have it, use it, or occupy it. You can also say that two people share something.
If you share a task, duty, or responsibility with someone, you each carry out or accept part of it. You can also say that two people share something.

The glass shattered into pieces.
The vase shattered into pieces when he dropped it.
It fell on the floor, but thankfully it didn't shatter into pieces.

voca.means_ko:
[쉬ft]
(장소를) 옮기다, 이동하다, 자세를 바꾸다, 
바뀌다, 옮기다, 대체하다
잽싸게 움직이다, 서두르다, 
(위치, 입장, 방향의) 변화, 전환, 변경, 교대
(특정 교대근무를 하는) 교대조
voca.means_en:
If you shift something or if it shifts, it moves slightly.
If someone's opinion, a situation, or a policy shifts or is shifted, it changes slightly.
If someone shifts the responsibility or blame for something onto you, they unfairly make you responsible or make people blame you for it, instead of them.
If a shop or company shifts goods, they sell goods that are difficult to sell.
If you shift gears in a car, you put the car into a different gear.
If a group of factory workers, nurses, or other people work shifts, they work for a set period before being replaced by another group, so that there is always a group working. Each of these set periods is called a shift. You can also use shift to refer to a group of workers who work together on a particular shift.

voca.means_ko:
[^쉬버r]
(추위, 두려움, 흥분 등으로 가볍게) (몸을) 떨다, 
와들와들 떨다, 흔들리다, 전율하다
몸의 떨림, 오한, 전율, 몸서리,
voca.means_en:
When you shiver, your body shakes slightly because you are cold or frightened.
He felf a shiver go down his spine.
"I can't go back in" said Annie, shivering.
As they walked with Morgan through the great hall, Jack shivered.
A shiver went up Jack's spine.

voca.means_ko: [^솨rk]\n(정신적) 충격, 충격적인 일, (의학적인) 쇼크\n충격을 주다, 깜짝 놀라게 하다,
voca.means_en:
shock / appal / horrify / disgust / sicken / repel / revolt
If you have a shock, something suddenly happens which is unpleasant, upsetting, or very surprising.
Shock is a person's emotional and physical condition when something very frightening or upsetting has happened to them.
If someone is in shock, they are suffering from a serious physical condition in which their blood is not flowing round their body properly, for example because they have had a bad injury.
A shock is the force of something suddenly hitting or pulling something else.
A shock is the same as an electric shock.
A shock of hair is a very thick mass of hair on a person's head.
If something shocks you, it makes you feel very upset, because it involves death or suffering and because you had not expected it.
If someone or something shocks you, it upsets or offends you because you think it is rude or morally wrong.

voca.means_ko: [슈우]\n쉬이/훠이라고 하다 (특히 손을 내저으며 무엇을 쫓는 것을 가리킴)\n(아이, 동물에게 하는 말로) 저리 가
voca.means_en: If you shoo an animal or a person away, you make them go away by waving your hands or arms at them.\nYou say 'shoo!' to an animal when you want it to go away.\n
A shooting star is a piece of rock or metal that burns very brightly when it enters the earth's atmosphere from space, and is seen from earth as a bright star travelling very fast across the sky.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^쇼울더r]
어깨, 어깨가 ~한, 
(도로의) 갓길
~을 어깨로 밀다, 어깨로 밀치고 나아가다
(책임을)~ 을 짊어지다
voca.means_en:
Your shoulders are between your neck and the tops of your arms.
The shoulders of a piece of clothing are the parts that cover your shoulders.
When you talk about someone's problems or responsibilities, you can say that they carry them on their shoulders.
A shoulder is a joint of meat from the upper part of the front leg of an animal.
If you shoulder the responsibility or the blame for something, you accept it.
If you shoulder something heavy, you put it across one of your shoulders so that you can carry it more easily.
If you shoulder someone aside or if you shoulder your way somewhere, you push past people roughly using your shoulder.
If someone offers you a shoulder to cry on or is a shoulder to cry on, they listen sympathetically as you talk about your troubles.
If you say that someone or something stands head and shoulders above other people or things, you mean that they are a lot better than them.
He pulled it arund his shoulders and buttoned it at the neck.

voca.means_ko:
[쉬^릑-k]
(흥분, 공포감, 고통 등으로) 소리/비명 지르다, 
(날카롭게) 악을 쓰며 말하다,  꽥 소리를 지르다
비명지르다, 새된 소리로 울다
비명, 외침
voca.means_en:
When someone shrieks, they make a short, very loud cry, for example because they are suddenly surprised, are in pain, or are laughing.
If you shriek something, you shout it in a loud, high-pitched voice.
A shriek of fury came from inside the cave.
"It's still coming!" he shrieked.
The two sentries left their watch and flew at Teddy with short shrieks.
"Traitor!" the Raven King shrieked at Rok.

voca.means_ko:
[^씩k]
병든, 아픈
(속이) 메스꺼운, 토할 것 같은, 멀미가 나느
역겨운
토사물
voca.means_en:
If you are sick, you are ill. Sick usually means physically ill, but it can sometimes be used to mean mentally ill.
If you are sick, the food that you have eaten comes up from your stomach and out of your mouth. If you feel sick, you feel as if you are going to be sick.
If you say that you are sick of something or sick and tired of it, you are emphasizing that you are very annoyed by it and want it to stop.
If you describe something such as a joke or story as sick, you mean that it deals with death or suffering in an unpleasantly humorous way.
Sick is vomit.

voca.means_ko:
[싸잇t]
시력, (눈으로 불수 있는 범위) 시야, 광경
보기, 봄
(특히 찾고 있던 것을) 갑자기 보다/찾다
voca.means_en:
sight / view / vision
Someone's sight is their ability to see.
The sight of something is the act of seeing it or an occasion on which you see it.
A sight is something that you see.
The sights are the places that are interesting to see and that are often visited by tourists.
If you sight someone or something, you suddenly see them, often briefly.
You can use a sight to mean a lot. For example, if you say that something is a sight worse than it was before, you are emphasizing that it is much worse than it was.
He caught sight of armor glinting in the sunlight.
With his raven sight, he saw walls packed with dried mud, animal fur, vines, and sticks.

to sign a document saying that you agree to work for somebody, play for their team, etc.; to persuade somebody to do this
to arrange to do a course of study by adding your name or somebody else's name to the list of people doing it
to agree to become a member of the armed forces; to persuade somebody to do this

voca.means_ko:
[싸일런t]
말을 안하는, 침북을 지키는, 조용한, 
고요한, 말없는
무언의, 묵시적인, 발음되지 않는, 묵음인
voca.means_en:
Someone who is silent is not speaking.
If you describe someone as a silent person, you mean that they do not talk to people very much, and sometimes give the impression of being unfriendly.
A place that is silent is completely quiet, with no sound at all. Something that is silent makes no sound at all.
A silent emotion or action is not expressed in speech.
A silent film has pictures usually accompanied by music but does not have the actors' voices or any other sounds.
It fell silently into a heap at Jack and Annie's feet.\n

The simplicity of something is the fact that it is not complicated and can be understood or done easily.\nWhen you talk about something's simplicity, you approve of it because it has no unnecessary parts or complicated details.\n
If you say that someone is sincere, you approve of them because they really mean the things they say. You can also describe someone's behaviour and beliefs as sincere.\n

If you say or feel something sincerely, you really mean or feel it, and are not pretending.
In Britain, people write 'Yours sincerely' before their signature at the end of a formal letter when they have addressed it to someone by name. In the United States, people usually write 'Sincerely yours' or 'Sincerely' instead.
I called my mother and sincerely apologized.

voca.means_ko:
[신k]
(액체나 부드러운 물질 아래로) 가라앉다, 빠지다, 
침몰하다, 침하하다, 주저앉다
(목소리가) 작아지다
개수대, 하수구, 수채통
voca.means_en:
sink - sank - sunken
A sink is a large fixed container in a kitchen, with taps to supply water. It is mainly used for washing dishes.
A sink is the same as a washbasin or basin.
If a boat sinks or if someone or something sinks it, it disappears below the surface of a mass of water.
If something sinks, it disappears below the surface of a mass of water.
If something sinks, it moves slowly downwards.
If something sinks to a lower level or standard, it falls to that level or standard.
People use sink school or sink estate to refer to a school or housing estate that is in a very poor area with few resources.
"Oh, no" Jack's heart sank.
Then Jack's knees gave way, and he sank to the ground.
to stay the night at somebody else's home\n

voca.means_ko: [슬^립오버r]\n(아이들이나 청소년들이 한 집에 모여) 함께 자며 놀기, 밤샘 파티
voca.means_en: A sleepover is an occasion when someone, especially a child, sleeps for one night in a place such as a friend's home.\n

voca.means_ko: [슬렌더r]\n날씬한, 호리호리한, 가느다란, \n(양, 크기가) 얼마 안되는, 빈약한
voca.means_en:
A slender person is attractively thin and graceful.
You can use slender to describe a situation which exists but only to a very small degree.
Annie held Jack's right hand as he grasped the slender golden hand of the dancer on his left.
It was only slightly warmer inside, But at least the wind wasn't blowing.\nThe bird was crouching, slightly spreading its wings.\n

It hadn't slipped my mind completely.
I had a meeting, but it slipped my mind.
I had something to tell her, but it had slipped my mind.

If you describe someone's work or activities as sloppy, you mean they have been done in a careless and lazy way.\nIf you describe someone or something as sloppy, you mean that they are sentimental and romantic.\n

If you slurp a liquid, you drink it noisily.
A slurp is a noise that you make with your mouth when you drink noisily, or a mouthful of liquid that you drink noisily.
They were gnawing meat off bones and slurping wine from heavy goblets.
He was slurping ice cream froma a cone.

Smoke consists of gas and small bits of solid material that are sent into the air when something burns.
If something is smoking, smoke is coming from it.
When someone smokes a cigarette, cigar, or pipe, they suck the smoke from it into their mouth and blow it out again. If you smoke, you regularly smoke cigarettes, cigars, or a pipe.
If fish or meat is smoked, it is hung over burning wood so that the smoke preserves it and gives it a special flavour.
If someone says there's no smoke without fire or where there's smoke there's fire, they mean that there are rumours or signs that something is true so it must be at least partly true.
If something goes up in smoke, it is destroyed by fire.
If something that is very important to you goes up in smoke, it fails or ends without anything being achieved.

voca.means_ko:
[s^머r-쥐]
더러움, 얼룩, 오점
(더러운) 자국, 얼룩
~을 더럽히다, (명성을) 손상하다
(특히 잉크, 페인트가 지저분하게) 번지게 하다, 번지다
(더러운) 자국/얼룩을 남기다
voca.means_en:
A smudge is a dirty mark.
If you smudge a substance such as ink, paint, or make-up that has been put on a surface, you make it less neat by touching or rubbing it.
If you smudge a surface, you make it dirty by touching it and leaving a substance on it.

voca.means_ko:
[s^넵]
탁 부러지다, 부러뜨리다, 
(동물이) 물려고 하다, 덥석 물다
사진을 찍다
급히하는, 즉석의, 쉬운, 수월한
성급한, 불시의
voca.means_en:
photograph / photo / picture / shot / snapshot / snap / portrait
If something snaps or if you snap it, it breaks suddenly, usually with a sharp cracking noise.
If you snap something into a particular position, or if it snaps into that position, it moves quickly into that position, with a sharp sound.
If you snap your fingers, you make a sharp sound by moving your middle finger quickly across your thumb, for example in order to accompany music or to order someone to do something.
If someone snaps at you, they speak to you in a sharp, unfriendly way.
If someone snaps, or if something snaps inside them, they suddenly stop being calm and become very angry because the situation has become too tense or too difficult for them.
A snap decision or action is one that is taken suddenly, often without careful thought.
A snap is a photograph.
"Why are you laughing?" Jack snapped.
"Snap out of it, Arthur!" said Buster.

voca.means_ko:
[s^닉-k]
살금살금 걷다, 살짝 다가가다
비열한 사람, 고자질 하는 학생
은밀한, 몰래/슬그머니 하는
voca.means_en:
If you sneak somewhere, you go there very quietly on foot, trying to avoid being seen or heard.
If you sneak something somewhere, you take it there secretly.
If you sneak a look at someone or something, you secretly have a quick look at them.
I didn't mean to sneak up on you. / Do not try to sneak this.
I sneaked a cake when they were out of the room. / Did you sneak on me to the teacher?
We just sneaked past them, Remember?
But sometimes we like to sneak out of bed and play.
to approach somebody very quietly, so that they do not see or hear you until you reach them.\nThen while all the pirates are digging, we'll sneak up to the tree house.\n

When you sneeze, you suddenly take in your breath and then blow it down your nose noisily without being able to stop yourself, for example because you have a cold.
If you say that something is not to be sneezed at, you mean that it is worth having.
She let out a loud sneeze. / Oh, I really have to sneeze.
Sometimes Mr. Haney yelled at him for running through the halls. But he had been to the office only once-for putting sneezing powder on Mr. Ratburn's desk.

voca.means_ko:
[s^노rt]
콧바람을 불다, 들이 마시다, 
큰 소리로 웃다, 콧방귀 끼다
(말 등이) 코를 힝힝 거리다
거센 콧김, (증기 등을) 내뿜는 소리
씩씩거리며 말하다
voca.means_en:
When people or animals snort, they breathe air noisily out through their noses. People sometimes snort in order to express disapproval or amusement.
If someone snorts something, they say it in a way that shows contempt.
To snort a drug such as cocaine means to breathe it in quickly through your nose.
I'm going to snort cocaine first. / I could hear the snort and stamp of a horse.
The great man could barely suppress a snort. / The woolly mammoth snorted.
The four real keepers of the cauldron crawled closer to Jack and Annie, hissing and snorting blue fire.
Frank laughed so hard he snorted.
Don't write so that you can be understood, write so that you can't be misunderstood.\n

voca.means_ko:
[사-d]
꼴보기 싫은 놈, 재수없는 놈
(형용사와 함께 쓰요) 놈, 새끼,
골치 아픈 것
떼 (잔디), 땟장, ~에 잔디를 입히다
망할놈의 것, 빌어먹을 것
voca.means_en:
If someone calls another person or something such as a job a sod, they are expressing anger or annoyance towards that person or thing.
If someone uses an expression such as sod it, sod you, or sod that, they are expressing anger or showing that they do not care about something.
Sod all means 'nothing at all'.

floor / ground / land / earth / soil
Soil is the substance on the surface of the earth in which plants grow.
You can use soil in expressions like British soil to refer to a country's territory.
If you soil something, you make it dirty.
The volcanic rock crumbled and turned to soil.
Solar is used to describe things relating to the sun.\nSolar power is obtained from the sun's light and heat.\n

You use something to refer to a thing, situation, event, or idea, without saying exactly what it is.
You can use something to say that the description or amount that you are giving is not exact.
If you say that a person or thing is something or is really something, you mean that you are very impressed by them
You can use something in expressions like 'that's something' when you think that a situation is not very good but is better that it might have been.
Okay, I'll tell her you'll call back sometime after two.\n I can meet you sometime after seven.

You use sometimes to say that something happens on some occasions rather than all the time.\nSometimes Mr. Haney yelled at him for running through the halls. But he had been to the office only once-for putting sneezing powder on Mr. Ratburn's desk.\n

If something is going to happen soon, it will happen after a short time. If something happened soon after a particular time or event, it happened a short time after it.
If you say that something happens as soon as something else happens, you mean that it happens immediately after the other thing.
If you say that you would just as soon do something or you'd just as soon do it, you mean that you would prefer to do it.
The sorcerer threw a rope into the pit.\nTheir helper was the young sorcerer who was training as Morgan's apprentice!\n
Sought is the past tense and past participle of seek.\n"After Mordred's Dark Wizard cast his spell, the king sought help from the magicians of Camelot," Morgan said quietly.\n

voca.means_ko: (~에 대해) ~의 의사를 타진하다, 의향을 알아보다\n~을 타진해 보다
voca.means_en: to try to discover somebody's views, opinions, etc. on something, especially in an indirect way\n

voca.means_ko:
[s^빼이s]
(비어있는, 이용할 수 있는) 공간, 자리, 장소
(장소가) 넓찍함, 시원스러움
우주, 기간, 공간, 지면, 
(생각할 수 있는) 시간, (자기 마음대로 할 수 있는) 자유
일정한 간격을 두다
voca.means_en:
land / lot / ground / space / plot
You use space to refer to an area that is empty or available. The area can be any size. For example, you can refer to a large area outside as a large open space or to a small area between two objects as a small space.
A particular kind of space is the area that is available for a particular activity or for putting a particular kind of thing in.
If a place gives a feeling of space, it gives an impression of being large and open.
If you give someone space to think about something or to develop as a person, you allow them the time and freedom to do this.
The amount of space for a topic to be discussed in a document is the number of pages available to discuss the topic.
A space of time is a period of time.
Space is the area beyond the Earth's atmosphere, where the stars and planets are.
Space is the whole area within which everything exists.
If you space a series of things, you arrange them so that they are not all together but have gaps or intervals of time between them.

shine / gleam / glow / sparkle / glisten / shimmer / glitter / twinkle / glint
If something sparkles, it is clear and bright and shines with a lot of very small points of light.
Someone who sparkles is lively, intelligent, and witty.
Sparkles are small points of light caused by light reflecting off a clear bright surface.
The woman ninja's eyes sparkled.
On a hillside beyond the meadow, red and purple flowers sparkled like bright buttons.
Pale pearls, emeralds, and rubies shone and sparkled.

voca.means_ko: [s빽]\n(자세한) 설명서, 사양\n(특정한 기준에 맞추어) 디자인하다, 만들다
voca.means_en:
Someone's specs are their glasses.
The spec for something, especially a machine or vehicle, is its design and the features included in it.
If you do something on spec, you do it hoping to get something that you want, but without being asked or without being certain to get it.

voca.means_ko:
[s뻴]
(어떤 단어의) 철자를 말하다/쓰다, 
철자를 맞게 쓰다, 맞춤법에 맞게 글을 쓰다, 
(보통 나쁜 결과를) 가져오다, 의미하다
한동안, 잠깐 동안, 
마법, 주문, 마력, 매력
voca.means_en:
spell - spelt - spelt
When you spell a word, you write or speak each letter in the word in the correct order.
Someone who can spell knows the correct order of letters in words.
If something spells a particular result, often an unpleasant one, it suggests that this will be the result.
A spell of a particular type of weather or a particular activity is a short period of time during which this type of weather or activity occurs.
A spell is a situation in which events are controlled by a magical power.
After you left, Arthur defeated him, but not before Mordred's Dark Wizard cast a spell over the whole kingdom.
It had wings that looked as if they'd been spun from a thousand spiderwebs.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s삔]
회전, 돌리기, 젼해, 해석
~을 회전시키다, 실을 내다, 질주하다
(거미, 누에가) 실을 내다, 거미집/고치를 짓다, (실을) 잣다
voca.means_en:
spin - spun - spun
If something spins or if you spin it, it turns quickly around a central point.
When you spin washing, it is turned round and round quickly in a spin drier or a washing machine to get the water out.
If your head is spinning, you feel unsteady or confused, for example because you are drunk, ill, or excited.
If someone puts a certain spin on an event or situation, they interpret it and try to present it in a particular way.
The cat roared and spun around.
It had wings that looked as if they'd been spun from a thousand spiderwebs.

Your spine is the row of bones down your back.
The spine of a book is the narrow stiff part which the pages and covers are attached to.
Spines are also long, sharp points on an animal's body or on a plant.
Jack felt a chill run down his spine.
A shiver went up Jack's spine.

voca.means_ko:
[s쁴륏t]
정신, 영혼, 기분, 마음
기백, 기상, 활기, (공동체) 정신
태도, 자세
재빨리/감쪽같이 채어 가다
voca.means_en:
Your spirit is the part of you that is not physical and that consists of your character and feelings.
A person's spirit is the non-physical part of them that is believed to remain alive after their death.
A spirit is a ghost or supernatural being.
Spirit is the courage and determination that helps people to survive in difficult times and to keep their way of life and their beliefs.
Spirit is the liveliness and energy that someone shows in what they do.
The spirit in which you do something is the attitude you have when you are doing it.
A particular kind of spirit is the feeling of loyalty to a group that is shared by the people who belong to the group.
A particular kind of spirit is the set of ideas, beliefs, and aims that are held by a group of people.
The spirit of something such as a law or an agreement is the way that it was intended to be interpreted or applied.
You can refer to a person as a particular kind of spirit if they show a certain characteristic or if they show a lot of enthusiasm in what they are doing.
As Jack danced around in the circle, his heart leaped. His spirits soared.
His spirits sank. Except for the three rhymes, he'd taken no notes on their journey-not one.\n

Spiritual means relating to people's thoughts and beliefs, rather than to their bodies and physical surroundings.
Spiritual means relating to people's religious beliefs.
A spiritual is a religious song of the type originally sung by black slaves in America.

voca.means_ko:
[s^삣t]
(입에 든 음식등을) 뱉다, 침을 뱉다, 
(욕, 폭언 등을) 내뱉다, 
토하다, 질질흘러 내리다
침, (침 등을) 뱉기, (꼬치요리에 쓰이는)쇠꼬챙이
(비가) 조금/보슬보슬 내리다
voca.means_en:
Spit is the watery liquid produced in your mouth. You usually use spit to refer to an amount of it that has been forced out of someone's mouth.
A spit is a long rod which is pushed through a piece of meat and hung over an open fire to cook the meat.
A spit of land is a long, flat, narrow piece of land that sticks out into the sea.
If someone spits, they force an amount of liquid out of their mouth, often to show hatred or contempt.
If you spit liquid or food somewhere, you force a small amount of it out of your mouth.
If it is spitting, it is raining very lightly.
take the turkey off the spit, put it on a platter, and bring it to a table.
He yanked his hand away and knocked the spit off its legs.
"The tiger spit on the rat and the gnat." The whole class cracked up.
Someone's spouse is the person they are married to.\n

I had sprained my ankle.
It's a common injury to sprain one's ankle.
He couldn't walk properly because he had sprained his ankle.

voca.means_ko:
[s쁘^뤠d]
(접혀있던 것이) 펴지다, 펴다, 펼치다, 
퍼지다, 확산하다, 번지다, 펼치다, 벌리다
확산, 전파, 퍼짐, 보류, 침대시트
voca.means_en:
If you spread something somewhere, you open it out or arrange it over a place or surface, so that all of it can be seen or used easily.
If you spread your arms, hands, fingers, or legs, you stretch them out until they are far apart.
If you spread a substance on a surface or spread the surface with the substance, you put a thin layer of the substance over the surface.
If something spreads or is spread by people, it gradually reaches or affects a larger and larger area or more and more people.
If something such as a liquid, gas, or smoke spreads or is spread, it moves outwards in all directions so that it covers a larger area.
If you spread something over a period of time, it takes place regularly or continuously over that period, rather than happening at one time.
If you spread something such as wealth or work, you distribute it evenly or equally.
In the hush of the cold twilight, the dove spread its wings and flew into the Frog Creek woods.
The bird was crouching, slightly spreading its wings.

In fairy stories and legends, a sprite is a small, magic creature which lives near water.\nMorgan and Merlin do not even know I have it. A forest sprite, a cousin of my mother's, gave it to me, in case I was ever in urgent need.\n

voca.means_ko: 박차, 자극제, 원동력\n원동력/자극제가 되다, 자극하다\n(비유적으로) 박차를 가하다
voca.means_en:
If one thing spurs you to do another, it encourages you to do it.
If something spurs a change or event, it makes it happen faster or sooner.
Something that acts as a spur to something else encourages a person or organization to do that thing or makes it happen more quickly.
Spurs are small metal wheels with sharp points that are attached to the heels of a rider's boots. The rider uses them to make their horse go faster.

voca.means_ko:
[sk위-z]
(특히 손가락으로 꼭)짜다/쥐다, 
(무엇에서 액체를) 짜내다, ~을 짜다, 압박하다, 
(좁은곳에) 밀어 넣다, 비집고 들어가다
voca.means_en:
If you squeeze something, you press it firmly, usually with your hands.
If you squeeze a liquid or a soft substance out of an object, you get the liquid or substance out by pressing the object.
If you squeeze your eyes shut or if your eyes squeeze shut, you close them tightly, usually because you are frightened or to protect your eyes from something such as strong sunlight.
If you squeeze a person or thing somewhere or if they squeeze there, they manage to get through or into a small space.
If you squeeze something out of someone, you persuade them to give it to you, although they may be unwilling to do this.
If a government squeezes the economy, they put strict controls on people's ability to borrow money or on their own departments' freedom to spend money, in order to control the country's rate of inflation.
If you say that getting a number of people into a small space is a squeeze, you mean that it is only just possible for them all to get into it.
They squeezed throught the crack, then walked toward the gleaming cauldron.
Something that is squishy is soft and easy to squash.\nThere's squishy bread for dipping.\n
Stakeholders are people who have an interest in a company's or organization's affairs.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s^따r]
별, 항성, 별 모양의 것
스타(가수, 배우, 운동선수 등)
(주연으로) 출연하다
voca.means_en:
A star is a large ball of burning gas in space. Stars appear to us as small points of light in the sky on clear nights.
You can refer to a shape or an object as a star when it has four, five, or more points sticking out of it in a regular pattern.
You can say how many stars something such as a hotel or restaurant has as a way of talking about its quality, which is often indicated by a number of star-shaped symbols. The more stars something has, the better it is.
Famous actors, musicians, and sports players are often referred to as stars.
Predictions about people's lives which are based on astrology and appear regularly in a newspaper or magazine are sometimes referred to as the stars.
The movie starred my favorite actor.
This show stars a famous actor.
A new actor starred in that movie.

voca.means_ko:
[s따r-t]
(무엇을 하거나 사용하기) 시작하다, 
(어떤 일이) 시작되다, 시작되게 하다
(없던 일이) 생기다, (사업 등을) 시작하다
떠나다, 길을 나서다, 
(어떤 일, 것의) 시작
voca.means_en:
start / begin / start off / kick off / commence / open / get under way
If you start to do something, you do something that you were not doing before and you continue doing it.
When something starts, or if someone starts it, it takes place from a particular time.
If you start by doing something, or if you start with something, you do that thing first in a series of actions.
You use start to say what someone's first job was. For example, if their first job was that of a factory worker, you can say that they started as a factory worker.
When someone starts something such as a new business, they create it or cause it to begin.
If you start an engine, car, or machine, or if it starts, it begins to work.
If you start, your body suddenly moves slightly as a result of surprise or fear.

Stats are facts which are obtained from analysing information expressed in numbers. Stats is an abbreviation for 'statistics'.\nStats is a branch of mathematics concerned with the study of information that is expressed in numbers.\n

voca.means_ko: [s테이]\n(다른 곳에 가지 않고) 계속/그대로 있다/ 머무르다, \n지내다
voca.means_en:
If you stay where you are, you continue to be there and do not leave.
If you stay in a town, or hotel, or at someone's house, you live there for a short time.
If someone or something stays in a particular state or situation, they continue to be in it.
If you stay away from a place, you do not go there.
If you stay out of something, you do not get involved in it.
If you stay put, you remain somewhere.
to sleep at somebody's house for a night\n
Without talking, they pushed steadily through the trees and bushes, moving farther and farther from the keepers' cave.\n

voca.means_ko: [s띠-읠]\n~을 흠치다, 도둑질하다, 살며시 움직이다, 도루하다\n도둑질, 절도
voca.means_en:
steal - stole - stolen
If you steal something from someone, you take it away from them without their permission and without intending to return it.
If you steal someone else's ideas, you pretend that they are your own.
If someone steals somewhere, they move there quietly, in a secret way.

voca.means_ko: 페달을 밟고 여는, (페달을) 밟다, 발을 걸다
voca.means_en: Oh, I'm really sorry, it was me! I stepped on your foot.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s띡k]
(보통 뾰족한 것을) 찌르다/박다, 찔리다, 
들러붙게하다, (~에 끼어) 꼼작 못하다
(특히 아무렇게나 급히) 집어 넣다/놓다
(부러진, 떨어진) 나뭇가지, 막대기, 접착성
voca.means_en:
stick - stuck - stuck
A stick is a thin branch which has fallen off a tree.
A stick is a long thin piece of wood which is used for supporting someone's weight or for hitting people or animals.
A stick is a long thin piece of wood which is used for a particular purpose.
If you stick something somewhere, you put it there in a rather casual way.
If you stick a pointed object in something, or if it sticks in something, it goes into it or through it by making a cut or hole.
If something is sticking out from a surface or object, it extends up or away from it. If something is sticking into a surface or object, it is partly in it.
If you gamble, if you invest in something and you put all your money into this investment, then you're sticking your neck out.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s^띠f]
뻣뻣한, 뻑뻑한, (근육이) 결리는, 뻐근한
심한, 힘든, 딱딱한, 경직된
몹시, 극심하게, 꽁꽁 언
시체
voca.means_en:
Something that is stiff is firm or does not bend easily.
Something such as a door or drawer that is stiff does not move as easily as it should.
If you are stiff, your muscles or joints hurt when you move, because of illness or because of too much exercise.
Stiff behaviour is rather formal and not very friendly or relaxed.
Stiff can be used to mean difficult or severe.
The boots were really stiff.
Generally, we do use this for women. For men, we say: "Loosen your tie". It's the same idea. "To loosen the tie" means relax, don't be so serious, don't be so stiff. Relax, have fun, do whatever you want. Tomorrow's another day, so let your hair down.

voca.means_ko:
[s띨]
조용하게 하다, 잠잠하게 하다, 진정시키다
정지해 있는, 움직이지 않는, 차분한
아직도 (계속해서), 여전히
(비교급으로) 훨씬, 더욱, 그럼에도 불구하고
voca.means_en:
If a situation that used to exist still exists, it has continued and exists now.
If something that has not yet happened could still happen, it is possible that it will happen. If something that has not yet happened is still to happen, it will happen at a later time.
If you stay still, you stay in the same position and do not move.
If air or water is still, it is not moving.
A still is a photograph taken from a cinema film which is used for publicity purposes.
Couldn't you still sell it today at the sale price?

voca.means_ko:
[s띠뮬레잇t]
자극하다, 격려하다, 활발하게 하다
흥미/관심을 불러 일으키다, 흥분시키다, 고무하다
(신체의 기능을) 활성화시키다
voca.means_en:
To stimulate something means to encourage it to begin or develop further.
If you are stimulated by something, it makes you feel full of ideas and enthusiasm.
If something stimulates a part of a person's body, it causes it to move or start working.

voca.means_ko:
[s띵]
~을 찌르다, 쏘다
따끔거리다, 따갑다/쓰라리다
화나게/기분 상하게 하다
독침, 가시, 찌르기, 쏘기, 따가움, 쓰라림, 얼얼함
voca.means_en:
sting - stung - stung
hurt / ache / burn / sting / tingle / throb
If a plant, animal, or insect stings you, a sharp part of it, usually covered with poison, is pushed into your skin so that you feel a sharp pain.
If a part of your body stings, or if a substance stings it, you feel a sharp pain there.
If someone's remarks sting you, they make you feel hurt and annoyed.
The sting of an insect or animal is the part that stings you.
If you feel a sting, you feel a sharp pain in your skin or other part of your body.
Salty spray stung Jack's eyes

Stockings are items of women's clothing which fit closely over their feet and legs. Stockings are usually made of nylon or silk and are held in place by suspenders.\nA stocking is the same as a Christmas stocking.\n

voca.means_ko:
[st뤠인]
부담, 중압감, 압력, 압박, 
긴장, 접질리기, 염좌
(근육 등을) 혹사하다, 염좌를 입다
긴장시키다, 경직되다, 삐다, 접지르다
한계에 이르게 하다, 무리를 주다
세게 잡아당기다, 꽉 죄다
voca.means_en:
injure / wound / hurt / bruise / maim / sprain / pull / twist / strain
If strain is put on an organization or system, it has to do more than it is able to do.
Strain is a state of worry and tension caused by a difficult situation.
If you say that a situation is a strain, you mean that it makes you worried and tense.
Strain is a force that pushes, pulls, or stretches something in a way that may damage it.
Strain is an injury to a muscle in your body, caused by using the muscle too much or twisting it.
You can use strain to refer to a particular quality in someone's character, remarks, or work.
A strain of a germ, plant, or other organism is a particular type of it.
To strain something means to make it do more than it is able to do.
If you strain a muscle, you injure it by using it too much or twisting it.

Straw consists of the dried, yellowish stalks from crops such as wheat or barley.
A straw is a thin tube of paper or plastic, which you use to suck a drink into your mouth.
If you are clutching at straws or grasping at straws, you are trying unusual or extreme ideas or methods because other ideas or methods have failed.
If an event is the last straw or the straw that broke the camel's back, it is the latest in a series of unpleasant or undesirable events, and makes you feel that you cannot tolerate a situation any longer.

Your strength is the physical energy that you have, which gives you the ability to perform various actions, such as lifting or moving things.

The strength of an object or material is its ability to be treated roughly, or to carry heavy weights, without being damaged or destroyed.
The strength of a person, organization, or country is the power or influence that they have.
If you refer to the strength of a feeling, opinion, or belief, you are talking about how deeply it is felt or believed by people, or how much they are influenced by it.
Someone's strengths are the qualities and abilities that they have which are an advantage to them, or which make them successful.

Though he still sounded hoarse, the knight's deep voice carried an amazing strength.

things / stuff / possessions / junk / belongings / goods / valuables
You can use stuff to refer to things such as a substance, a collection of things, events, or ideas, or the contents of something in a general way without mentioning the thing itself by name.
If you stuff something somewhere, you push it there quickly and roughly.
If you stuff a container or space with something, you fill it with something or with a quantity of things until it is full.
If you stuff yourself, you eat a lot of food.
If you stuff a bird such as a chicken or a vegetable such as a pepper, you put a mixture of food inside it before cooking it.
If a dead animal is stuffed, it is filled with a substance so that it can be preserved and displayed.

"It's the great hall," he said "where they have feasts and stuff."

Stuffy people or institutions are formal and old-fashioned.

A suffix is a letter or group of letters, for example '-ly' or '-ness', which is added to the end of a word in order to form a different word, often of a different word class. For example, the suffix '-ly' is added to 'quick' to form 'quickly'.\nA suffix is one or more numbers or letters added to the end of a code number to indicate, for example, what area something belongs to.\n

A man's suit consists of a jacket, trousers, and sometimes a waistcoat, all made from the same fabric.
A woman's suit consists of a jacket and skirt, or sometimes trousers, made from the same fabric.
A particular type of suit is a piece of clothing that you wear for a particular activity.
If something suits you, it is convenient for you or is the best thing for you in the circumstances.
If something suits you, you like it.
If a piece of clothing or a particular style or colour suits you, it makes you look attractive.

I pack clothes that are suitable for the weather.
I don't think your jacket is suitable for the weather.
This outfit is not suitable for the weather.
A suitcase is a box or bag with a handle and a hard frame in which you carry your clothes when you are travelling.\nJason: I think I've done everything but pack my suitcase.\n

If you describe something as superlative, you mean that it is extremely good.
In grammar, the superlative form of an adjective or adverb is the form that indicates that something has more of a quality than anything else in a group. For example, 'biggest' is the superlative form of 'big'. Compare comparative.
If someone uses superlatives to describe something, they use adjectives and expressions which indicate that it is extremely good.

You can use suppose or supposing before mentioning a possible situation or action. You usually then go on to consider the effects that this situation or action might have.
If you suppose that something is true, you believe that it is probably true, because of other things that you know.
You can say 'I suppose' when you want to express slight uncertainty.
You can say 'I suppose' or 'I don't suppose' before describing someone's probable thoughts or attitude, when you are impatient or slightly angry with them.
You can say 'I don't suppose' as a way of introducing a polite request.
"I suppose we must say good-bye now," he said to Jack and Annie.

If you say that something is supposed to happen, you mean that it is planned or expected. Sometimes this use suggests that the thing does not really happen in this way.
If something was supposed to happen, it was planned or intended to happen, but did not in fact happen.
If you say that something is supposed to be true, you mean that people say it is true but you do not know for certain that it is true.
You can use 'be supposed to' to express annoyance at someone's ideas, or because something is not happening in the proper way.

Surgery is medical treatment in which someone's body is cut open so that a doctor can repair, remove, or replace a diseased or damaged part.
A surgery is the room or house where a doctor or dentist works.
A doctor's surgery is the period of time each day when a doctor sees patients at his or her surgery.
In Britain, when someone such as an MP or a local councillor holds a surgery, they go to an office where members of the public can come and talk to them about problems or issues that concern them.
A surgery is the room in a hospital where surgeons operate on their patients.

I can swing by your house and take you.

A syringe is a small tube with a thin hollow needle at the end. Syringes are used for putting liquids into things and for taking liquids out, for example for injecting drugs or for taking blood from someone's body.\n

A system is a way of working, organizing, or doing something which follows a fixed plan or set of rules. You can use system to refer to an organization or institution that is organized in this way.

Your system is your body's organs and other parts that together perform particular functions.

Territory is land which is controlled by a particular country or ruler.

You use thank you or, in more informal English, thanks to express your gratitude when someone does something for you or gives you what you want.
You use thank you or, in more informal English, thanks to politely accept or refuse something that has just been offered to you.
You use thank you or, in more informal English, thanks to politely acknowledge what someone has said to you, especially when they have answered your question or said something nice to you.
You use thank you or thank you very much in order to say firmly that you do not want someone's help or to tell them that you do not like the way that they are behaving towards you.
When you thank someone for something, you express your gratitude to them for it.
When you express your thanks to someone, you express your gratitude to them for something.

Then means at a particular time in the past or in the future.

You use then in conversation to indicate that what you are about to say follows logically in some way from what has just been said or implied.
You use then at the end of a topic or at the end of a conversation.
You use then with words like 'now', 'well', and 'okay', to introduce a new topic or a new point of view.
You use then to introduce the second part of a sentence which begins with 'if'. The first part of the sentence describes a possible situation, and then introduces the result of the situation.

A person's thoughts are their opinions on a particular subject.

If you refer to thousands of things or people, you are emphasizing that there are very many of them.

When it thunders, a loud noise comes from the sky after a flash of lightning.
If something or someone thunders somewhere, they move there quickly and with a lot of noise.

If someone is trampled, they are injured or killed by being stepped on by animals or by other people.
If someone tramples something or tramples on it, they step heavily and carelessly on it and damage it.
to ignore somebody's feelings or rights and treat them as if they are not important\n

voca.means_ko:
[츄뤱]
올가미, 덫, 함정, 배수관
(위험한 장소, 궁지에) 가두다, 
(몸의 일부, 옷 등이) 끼이다, 옥죄이다, 
덫으로 잡다, 덫을 놓다, 가두다, 잡다, 끼이다,
voca.means_en:
A trap is a device which is placed somewhere or a hole which is dug somewhere in order to catch animals or birds.
A trap is a trick that is intended to catch or deceive someone.
A trap is an unpleasant situation that you cannot easily escape from.
If a person traps animals or birds, he or she catches them using traps.
If you trap someone into doing or saying something, you trick them so that they do or say it, although they did not want to.
To trap someone, especially a criminal, means to capture them.
"I don't know," said Jack. "We're trapped."

voca.means_ko:
[^튜롸블]
(특히 장거리를) 여행하다
(특정한 속도로, 방향으로, 거리를) 이동하다, 가다
여행, 출장, 이동, 기행문
voca.means_en:
If you travel, you go from one place to another, often to a place that is far away.
If you travel the world, the country, or the area, you go to many different places in the world or in a particular country or area.
When light or sound from one place reaches another, you say that it travels to the other place.
When news becomes known by people in different places, you can say that it travels to them.
Travel is the activity of travelling.
Someone's travels are the journeys that they make to places a long way from their home.
China is one of the most common travel destinations in Asia. Some people go there on vacation, while others go on business.\n

voca.means_ko: (짐을 아주 적게 가지고) 가볍게 여행하다\n짐을 가볍게 싸고 여행을 하다
voca.means_en:
travel with very little luggage
Some people travel light.
I learned how to travel light.
It's more convenient to travel light.

voca.means_ko:
[^튜뤠d]
(발을) 디디다, 밟다, 
걷다, 걸음을 옮기다, 밟다, (새) 교미하다
밟아서 으께다/뭉개다
걸음걸이, 발소리, 
(계단의) 디딤판
밟기, 걷기, 발자국, 족적, (새) 교미
voca.means_en:
tread - trod - trodden
If you tread on something, you put your foot on it when you are walking or standing.
If you tread in a particular way, you walk that way.
If you tread carefully, you behave in a careful or cautious way.
A person's tread is the sound that they make with their feet as they walk.
The tread of a step or stair is its flat upper surface.
The tread of a tyre or shoe is the pattern of thin lines cut into its surface that stops it slipping.
If someone is treading a fine line or path, they are acting carefully because they have to avoid making a serious mistake, especially in a situation where they have to deal with two opposing demands.

voca.means_ko:
[튜^뤳미얼]
발로 밟아 돌리는 바퀴, (런닝머신)
(특히 과거의) 발로 밟아 돌리는 기구
다람쥐 쳇바퀴 같은 일[생활]
트레드밀(걷기나 달리기용 운동 기구)
voca.means_en: You can refer to a task or a job as a treadmill when you have to keep doing it although it is unpleasant and exhausting.\nA treadmill is a piece of equipment, for example an exercise machine, consisting of a wheel with steps around its edge or a continuous moving belt. The weight of a person or animal walking on it causes the wheel or belt to turn.\n
said by children who visit people's houses at Halloween (= October 31) and threaten to play tricks on people who do not give them sweets/candy\n

voca.means_ko:
[튜림]
다듬다, 깍아서 손질하다, 치장하다
정돈되어 있음, 장비, 장구, 상태, 기분
깔끔한, 말쑥한, 단정한, 정돈된
깔끔하게, 정된되어, 말쑥하게
voca.means_en:
Something that is trim is neat, tidy, and attractive.
If you describe someone's figure as trim, you mean that it is attractive because there is no extra fat on their body.
If you trim something, for example someone's hair, you cut off small amounts of it in order to make it look neater and tidier.
If a government or other organization trims something such as a plan, policy, or amount, they reduce it slightly in extent or size.
If something such as a piece of clothing is trimmed with a type of material or design, it is decorated with it, usually along its edges.
The trim on something such as a piece of clothing is a decoration, for example along its edges, that is in a different colour or material.

Tropical means belonging to or typical of the tropics.
Tropical weather is hot and damp weather that people believe to be typical of the tropics.
Southeast Asia has many tropical resorts. Korean tourists like to visit those locations for their vacations or honeymoons.

voca.means_ko:
[^튜러벌]
애, 문제, 곤란, 고민, 골칫거리
병, 통증, 
(기계, 차량 등에 생긴) 문제, 고장
~을 괴롭히다, 애먹이다, 
귀찮게 하다, 실례하다, 
휘젓다
voca.means_en:
illness / sickness / ill health / trouble
You can refer to problems or difficulties as trouble.
If you say that one aspect of a situation is the trouble, you mean that it is the aspect which is causing problems or making the situation unsatisfactory.
Your troubles are the things that you are worried about.
If you have kidney trouble or back trouble, for example, there is something wrong with your kidneys or your back.
If there is trouble somewhere, especially in a public place, there is fighting or rioting there.
If you tell someone that it is no trouble to do something for them, you are saying politely that you can or will do it, because it is easy or convenient for you.
If you say that a person or animal is no trouble, you mean that they are very easy to look after.
If something troubles you, it makes you feel rather worried.
If a part of your body troubles you, it causes you physical pain or discomfort.
If you say that someone does not trouble to do something, you are critical of them because they do not behave in the way that they should do, and you think that this would require very little effort.

You use truly to emphasize that something has all the features or qualities of a particular thing, or is the case to the fullest possible extent.
You can use truly in order to emphasize your description of something.
You use truly to emphasize that feelings are genuine and sincere.
You write Yours truly at the end of a formal letter to someone you do not know very well. You write your signature after the words 'Yours truly'.
You can say yours truly as a way of referring to yourself.

voca.means_ko: [츄렁k]\n(나무) 줄기, 나무의 몸통, 대형 여행가방, 코끼리 코\n(사람의) 몸통
voca.means_en:
The trunk of a tree is the large main stem from which the branches grow.
A trunk is a large, strong case or box used for storing things or for taking on a journey.
An elephant's trunk is its very long nose that it uses to lift food and water to its mouth.
The trunk of a car is a covered space at the back or front in which you put luggage or other things.
Trunks are shorts that a man wears when he goes swimming.
Your trunk is the central part of your body, from your neck to your waist.
They slipped through the narrow doorway into the bright hollow of the tree trunk.

voca.means_ko:
[^턱k]
(끝 부분을 단정하게) 밀어넣다, 접다, 
(작은 공간에) 집어 넣다, 끼워넣다, 쑤셔넣다, 
감추다, 걷어붙이다, 밀어넣다, 접다
지방제거 수술
voca.means_en:
If you tuck something somewhere, you put it there so that it is safe, comfortable, or neat.
You can use tuck to refer to a form of plastic surgery which involves reducing the size of a part of someone's body.
She tucked it inside her sock.
The king's giant nest was tucked under a rocky overhang.

voca.means_ko:
[터g]
(세게, 흔히 여러 번) 잡아 당기다, ~을 세게 당기다, 
질질끌다, 예인하다, 세게 잡아당기기, 질질끌기
예인선, (갑가지 세게) 잡아당김
voca.means_en:
pull / drag / draw / haul / tow / tug
If you tug something or tug at it, you give it a quick and usually strong pull.
A tug or a tug boat is a small powerful boat which pulls large ships, usually when they come into a port.
"Tug on the rope" said Annie.
Morgan tugged on one of Annie's braids.
to turn on the radio or television in order to listen or watch a programme or channel\nto be aware of, or understand other people's thoughts feelings or needs\n
to turn on the radio or television in order to listen or watch a programme or channel\nto be aware of, or understand other people's thoughts feelings or needs\n

voca.means_ko:
나타나다, 참석하다,
밝혀지다, 드러나다
(일, 진행·결과가 특정 방식으로) 되다, 되어 가다
바깥쪽으로 향하다
~인 것으로 드러나다, 밝혀지다
voca.means_en:
to be present at an event; to attend something or to go somewhere
(used with an adverb, an adjective or in questions with) to take place or happen in the way mentioned; to develop or end in a particular way
Les: Are you happy with the way the elections turned out?
I'm sure the party will turn out fine.

A twig is a very small thin branch that grows out from a main branch of a tree or bush.
If you twig, you suddenly realize or understand something.
She pointed to the scrolls from Shakespeare's theater and the twig from the gorillas.

voca.means_ko:
[투윙클]
반짝거리다, 반짝반짝 빛나다
(눈이 행복감, 흥분으로) 반짝거리다, 빛나다
반짝거림, 빛남, 반짝이는 빛
voca.means_en:
shine / gleam / glow / sparkle / glisten / shimmer / glitter / twinkle / glint
If a star or a light twinkles, it shines with an unsteady light which rapidly and constantly changes from bright to faint.
If you say that someone's eyes twinkle, you mean that their face expresses good humour or amusement.

voca.means_ko: 몸이 좀 않좋은\n날씨 탓으로, 기분이 개운치 않은, 좀 취해서.
voca.means_en: slightly ill, sick or depressed; not as well/cheerful as usual\nI've been feeling a bit under the weather lately.\n

Underpants are a piece of underwear which have two holes to put your legs through and elastic around the top to hold them up round your waist or hips. In British English, underpants refers to only men's underwear but in American English it refers to both men's and women's.\n

If something such as an action or an event underscores another, it draws attention to the other thing and emphasizes its importance.\nIf you underscore something such as a word or a sentence, you draw a line underneath it in order to make people notice it or give it extra importance.\n

A union is a workers' organization which represents its members and which aims to improve things such as their working conditions and pay.
When the union of two or more things occurs, they are joined together and become one thing.
When two or more things, for example countries or organizations, have been joined together to form one thing, you can refer to them as a union.
Union is used in the name of some clubs, societies, and organizations.

The universe is the whole of space and all the stars, planets, and other forms of matter and energy in it.\nIf you talk about someone's universe, you are referring to the whole of their experience or an important part of it.\n

If something is urgent, it needs to be dealt with as soon as possible.
If you speak in an urgent way, you show that you are anxious for people to notice something or to do something.
Morgan and Merlin do not even know I have it. A forest sprite, a cousin of my mother's, gave it to me, in case I was ever in urgent need.
This is urgent. This has to be done today.
I'm utterly broke.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^붸이케잇t]
(건물, 좌석 등을 다른 사람이 이용할 수 있도록) 비우다
~을 비우다, 퇴거하다, 물러나다, 사임하다
(계약등을) 무효로 하다, 휴가를 떠나다
voca.means_en: If you vacate a place or a job, you leave it or give it up, making it available for other people.\n

holiday / vacation
A vacation is a period of the year when universities and colleges, and in the United States also schools, are officially closed.
A vacation is a period of time during which you relax and enjoy yourself away from home.
If you have a particular number of days' or weeks' vacation, you do not have to go to work for that number of days or weeks.
If you are vacationing in a place away from home, you are on vacation there.
I'm here on vacation.

voca.means_ko:
[봐이s]
(섹스, 마약이 관련된) 범죄
악, 악덕 행위, 비행
바이스(기계공작에서, 공작물을 끼워 고정하는 기구)
voca.means_en:
A vice is a habit which is regarded as a weakness in someone's character, but not usually as a serious fault.
Vice refers to criminal activities, especially those connected with pornography or prostitution.
A vice is a tool with a pair of parts that hold an object tightly while you do work on it.
Vice- is used before a rank or title to indicate that someone is next in importance to the person who holds the rank or title mentioned.

A victim is someone who has been hurt or killed.
A victim is someone who has suffered as a result of someone else's actions or beliefs, or as a result of unpleasant circumstances.
If you fall victim to something or someone, you suffer as a result of them, or you are killed by them.
At night, they quietly bite their victims and suck their blood.

When someone speaks or sings, you hear their voice.
Someone's voice is their opinion on a particular topic and what they say about it.
If you have a voice in something, you have the right to express an opinion on it.
In grammar, if a verb is in the active voice, the person who performs the action is the subject of the verb. If a verb is in the passive voice, the thing or person affected by the action is the subject of the verb.
If you voice something such as an opinion or an emotion, you say what you think or feel.
If you give voice to an opinion, a need, or a desire, you express it aloud.
If someone tells you to keep your voice down, they are asking you to speak more quietly.
The knight's voice rang out from inside his helmet.

If you vomit, food and drink comes back up from your stomach and out through your mouth.\nVomit is partly digested food and drink that has come back up from someone's stomach and out through their mouth.\n

A voucher is a ticket or piece of paper that can be used instead of money to pay for something.
She gave me a voucher for a free breakfast.
Here's a voucher for a cup of coffee.
He gave her a movie voucher as a gift.

A vowel is a sound such as the ones represented in writing by the letters 'a', 'e' 'I', 'o' and 'u', which you pronounce with your mouth open, allowing the air to flow through it. Compare consonant.\n

A vulture is a large bird which lives in hot countries and eats the flesh of dead animals.\nIf you describe a person as a vulture, you disapprove of them because you think they are trying to gain from another person's troubles.\n

If you wade through something that makes it difficult to walk, usually water or mud, you walk through it.
To wade through a lot of documents or pieces of information means to spend a lot of time and effort reading them or dealing with them.
Jack watched her wade into the water. / They started wading across.
"Let's wade into the water," said Annie.

voca.means_ko:
[웨읠]
(슬픔, 통증 때문에) 울부짖다, 통곡하다, 흐느끼다
(길고 높은) 소리를 내다/울리다
몹시 비통해 하다, 탄식하다
울부짖음, 통곡
voca.means_en:
If someone wails, they make long, loud, high-pitched cries which express sorrow or pain.
If you wail something, you say it in a loud, high-pitched voice that shows that you are unhappy or in pain.
If something such as a siren or an alarm wails, it makes a long, loud, high-pitched sound.
"I can't see them anymore!" wailed Annie.

wake - woke - woken
When you wake or when someone or something wakes you, you become conscious again after being asleep.
The wake of a boat or other object moving in water is the track of waves that it makes behind it as it moves through the water.
A wake is a gathering or social event that is held before or after someone's funeral.
If one thing follows in the wake of another, it happens after the other thing is over, often as a result of it.

voca.means_ko: (스포츠나 활동 전에) 몸을 천천히 풀다, 준비운동하다\n(잘 작동될 수 있도록) 적당히 열이 오르다
voca.means_en:
to become warmer
to do gentle exercise or practice to prepare for exercise, a performance, etc.
to run for a short time in order to reach the temperature at which it will operate well
They have to warm up before they go into the water.

The warmth of something is the heat that it has or produces.
The warmth of something such as a garment or blanket is the protection that it gives you against the cold.
Someone who has warmth is friendly and enthusiastic in their behaviour towards other people.

voca.means_ko:
[^왓취]
(시간, 관심을 기울이며) 보다, 지켜보다, 주시하다
(잠깐동안) 봐주다 
조심하다
(손목에 차는) 시계, 감시, 망 보기, 주시, 불침번
voca.means_en:
look / watch / see / view / observe/ regard
If you watch someone or something, you look at them, usually for a period of time, and pay attention to what is happening.
If you watch something on television or an event such as a sports match, you spend time looking at it, especially when you see it from the beginning to the end.
If you watch a situation or event, you pay attention to it or you are aware of it, but you do not influence it.
A watch is a period of carefully looking and listening, often while other people are asleep and often as a military duty, so that you can warn them of danger or an attack.
Watch, I'm going to take the hood off.
The two sentries left their watch and flew at Teddy with short shrieks.

voca.means_ko:
[웨이v]
물결치다, 흔들리다, 흔들다, 펄럭이다
(손, 팔을) 흔들다, 손짓하다
파도, 유행
(팔, 손, 몸을) 흔들기
voca.means_en:
If you wave or wave your hand, you move your hand from side to side in the air, usually in order to say hello or goodbye to someone.
If you wave someone away or wave them on, you make a movement with your hand to indicate that they should move in a particular direction.
If you wave something, you hold it up and move it rapidly from side to side.
If something waves, it moves gently from side to side or up and down.
A wave is a raised mass of water on the surface of water, especially the sea, which is caused by the wind or by tides making the surface of the water rise and fall.
If someone's hair has waves, it curves slightly instead of being straight.
Again and again, Jack was thrown down and slammed by breaking waves.
Amy: Yeah and now I'm way behind.\nIf you don't do your homework you'll be way behind your classmates.\n

If someone is weak, they are not healthy or do not have good muscles, so that they cannot move quickly or carry heavy things.
If someone has an organ or sense that is weak, it is not very effective or powerful, or is likely to fail.
If you describe someone as weak, you mean that they are not very confident or determined, so that they are often frightened or worried, or easily influenced by other people.
If you describe someone's voice or smile as weak, you mean that it not very loud or big, suggesting that the person lacks confidence, enthusiasm, or physical strength.
If an object or surface is weak, it breaks easily and cannot support a lot of weight or resist a lot of strain.

Wealth is the possession of a large amount of money, property, or other valuable things. You can also refer to a particular person's money or property as their wealth.\nIf you say that someone or something has a wealth of good qualities or things, you are emphasizing that they have a very large number or amount of them.\n

I had to wear an eye patch.
You won't have to wear on eye patch.
Wearing an eye patch is very annoying.

voca.means_ko:
[웨잇t]
무게, 체중, 무거운 것, 중요성, 가중치
(봉, 추 등을 매달아) 무겁게 하다, 무게를 주다
가중치를 두다
voca.means_en:
The weight of a person or thing is how heavy they are, measured in units such as kilograms, pounds, or tons.
A person's or thing's weight is the fact that they are very heavy.
If you move your weight, you change position so that most of the pressure of your body is on a particular part of your body.
Weights are objects which weigh a known amount and which people lift as a form of exercise.
Weights are metal objects which weigh a known amount and which are used on a set of scales to weigh other things.
You can refer to a heavy object as a weight, especially when you have to lift it.
If you weight something, you make it heavier by adding something to it, for example in order to stop it from moving easily.

voca.means_ko: ~인가뭔가\n(이름을 모르거나 정확하지 않은 무엇을 가리킬 때 씀)
voca.means_en: People sometimes say 'and whatnot' or 'or whatnot' after mentioning one or more things, to refer in a vague way to other things which are similar.\n
When in doubt, bottled water is the best bet.\n

when it is a case, matter or question of something/of doing something
when it is a question of something
When it comes to travelling, safety is a major concern.

voca.means_ko:
[웨r^에버r]
어디에나, 어디든지, 
(~한 곳) 어디에나, 모든 곳에
~한 모든 경우에, 언제나
voca.means_en:
You use wherever to indicate that something happens or is true in any place or situation.
You use wherever when you indicate that you do not know where a person or place is.
You use wherever in questions as an emphatic form of 'where', usually when you are surprised about something.

to prepare a meal or some food very quickly
if the wind whips up dust, waves, etc., it makes it/them rise quickly
I'm going to whip up a hamburger.

The whiskers of an animal such as a cat or a mouse are the long stiff hairs that grow near its mouth.
You can refer to the hair on a man's face, especially on the sides of his face, as his whiskers.
You can use whisker in expressions such as by a whisker or within a whisker of to indicate that something happened or is true, but only by a very small amount or degree.

voca.means_ko: [윗쓸]\n휘파람, 호각, 경적, (기차, 배 등의) 기적, 경적\n휘파람을 불다
voca.means_en:
When you whistle or when you whistle a tune, you make a series of musical notes by forcing your breath out between your lips, or your teeth.
When someone whistles, they make a sound by forcing their breath out between their lips or their teeth. People sometimes whistle when they are surprised or shocked, or to call a dog, or to show that they are impressed.
If something such as a train or a kettle whistles, it makes a loud, high sound.
If something such as the wind or a bullet whistles somewhere, it moves there, making a loud, high sound.
A whistle is a loud sound produced by air or steam being forced through a small opening, or by something moving quickly through the air.
A whistle is a small metal tube which you blow in order to produce a loud sound and attract someone's attention.
A whistle is a simple musical instrument in the shape of a metal pipe with holes.

voca.means_ko: [워-쉬]\n쉭 하는 소리 (공기, 물이 빠르게 지나가며 내는 소리)\n(아주 빠르게) 휙 하고 지나가다
voca.means_en:
People sometimes say 'whoosh' when they are emphasizing the fact that something happens very suddenly or very fast.
If something whooshes somewhere, it moves there quickly or suddenly.
Jack felt a wave of cold air whoosh past him.
Jack felt cold air whoosh by him again.
used in questions to mean 'why?', expressing surprise

voca.means_ko: [와이든]\n~을 넓히다, 넓어지다\n(정도, 범위 등이) 커지다, 확대되다, 키우다, 확대하다
voca.means_en:
If you widen something or if it widens, it becomes greater in measurement from one side or edge to the other.
If you widen something or if it widens, it becomes greater in range or it affects a larger number of people or things.
If your eyes widen, they open more.
If a difference or gap widens or if something widens it, it becomes greater.
Annie's eyes widened.
to gain somebody's support or approval, especially by persuading them that you are right\n

voca.means_ko:
[윈d]
바람, 강풍
(운동, 악기 연주때 필요한) 숨, 호흡
관악기
잠깐동안 숨 쉬기 어렵게 만들다, 
~을 숨차게 하다, 트림시키다

voca.means_en:
wind - wound - wound
A wind is a current of air that is moving across the earth's surface.
Journalists often refer to a trend or factor that influences events as a wind of a particular kind.
Wind is the air that you sometimes swallow with food or drink, or gas that is produced in your intestines, which causes an uncomfortable feeling.
If you are winded by something such as a blow, the air is suddenly knocked out of your lungs so that you have difficulty breathing for a short time
The wind section of an orchestra or band is the group of people who produce musical sounds by blowing into their instruments.

If a road, river, or line of people winds in a particular direction, it goes in that direction with a lot of bends or twists in it.
When you wind something flexible around something else, you wrap it around it several times.
When you wind a mechanical device, for example a watch or a clock, you turn a knob, key, or handle on it several times in order to make it operate.
To wind a tape or film back or forward means to make it move towards its starting or ending position.

(informal) to defeat somebody easily in a sports competition
(informal) to make somebody very tired
(slang) to murder somebody
