조금씩 나아가다, 움직이다, 이동시키다, 날을 갈다
voca.means_en:
The edge of something is the place or line where it stops, or the part of it that is furthest from the middle.
The edge of something sharp such as a knife or an axe is its sharp or narrow side.
The edge of something, especially something bad, is the point at which it may start to happen.
If someone or something has an edge, they have an advantage that makes them stronger or more likely to be successful than another thing or person.
He edged his way to the door. His mother had reached Mr. Haney's envelope.
Jason: It's more than I expected. Can you cut down the price a little?\n

If you describe someone as a fiend, you mean that they are extremely wicked or cruel.\nFiend can be used after a noun to refer to a person who is very interested in the thing mentioned, and enjoys having a lot of it or doing it often.\n

voca.means_ko: [^퓌겨러디v]\n(언어, 어구 등이) 비유적인, 수식 문구가 많은\n(그림, 조각 등이) 구상[조형]의
voca.means_en: If you use a word or expression in a figurative sense, you use it with a more abstract or imaginative meaning than its ordinary literal one.\nFigurative art is a style of art in which people and things are shown in a realistic way.\n

voca.means_ko:
[플^뤱]
펄럭이다, 휘날리다, 퍼덕이다
(새가 날개를) 퍼덕거리다, 퍼덕이다
펄럭임, 늘어진 물건, 뚜껑, 흥분 상태, 소동
voca.means_en:
If something such as a piece of cloth or paper flaps or if you flap it, it moves quickly up and down or from side to side.
If a bird or insect flaps its wings or if its wings flap, the wings move quickly up and down.
If you flap your arms, you move them quickly up and down as if they were the wings of a bird.
A flap of cloth or skin, for example, is a flat piece of it that can move freely up and down or from side to side because it is held or attached by only one edge.
Ropes flapped and snapped in the wild wind.
The red cloak flapped in the bitter wind.
Arthur put down his backpack on the counter. One corner of Mr. Haney's envelope was sticking out of the flap.
to turn over the pages of a book, etc. quickly, or look through a pile of papers, etc. without reading everything\nShe flipped through a magazine. \n
Sometimes, for a change of pace, we rearrange the furniture in the apartment.\n
Fortunately is used to introduce or indicate a statement about an event or situation that is good.\nAssistant: Fortunately, we have a very similar product here and it's cheaper.\n

I can get some sleep in the living room.
I'm so tired that I need to get some sleep.
Did you have time to get some sleep?
Jason: I think we should stop here. I think you're getting wasted.\n

voca.means_ko:
~와 연애하다
~에 포함되다, 딸려 나오다
(계획, 제의 등을) 받아들이다
(함께) 잘 어울리다
공존하다, 동반되다
voca.means_en:
to have a sexual or romantic relationship with somebody; to have sex with somebody
to look, taste, sound, etc. good with something; to combine well with something
to exist at the same time or in the same place as something; to be often found together
to be included with or as a part of something
High-end products, especially electronic products, are the most expensive of their kind.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^어니st]
(성품이) 정직한, (어떤 사실에 대해) 솔직한
순수/정직해 보이는
힘들게 한, 정직하게 번, 힘든 노력의 대가인
정말로, 참으로
voca.means_en:
honest / frank / direct / open / outspoken / straight / blunt
If you describe someone as honest, you mean that they always tell the truth, and do not try to deceive people or break the law.
If you are honest in a particular situation, you tell the complete truth or give your sincere opinion, even if this is not very pleasant.
You say 'honest' before or after a statement to emphasize that you are telling the truth and that you want people to believe you.
Some people say 'honest to God' to emphasize their feelings or to emphasize that something is really true.
You can say 'to be honest' before or after a statement to indicate that you are telling the truth about your own opinions or feelings, especially if you think these will disappoint the person you are talking to.
A housewarming is a party that you give for friends when you have just moved to a new house.\nAre you going to Lisa's housewarming party? \n

I have neighbors in all directions.
Before you go, look in all diretions.
The water spilled in all directions.

voca.means_ko:
[^이너썬t]
아무 잘못이 없는, 무죄인, 결백한, 
순결한 사람, 순진한 사람, 어린아이
죄 없는, 순수한, 선량한, 단순한
voca.means_en:
If someone is innocent, they did not commit a crime which they have been accused of.
If someone is innocent, they have no experience or knowledge of the more complex or unpleasant aspects of life.
Innocent people are those who are not involved in a crime or conflict, but are injured or killed as a result of it.
An innocent question, remark, or comment is not intended to offend or upset people, even if it does so.
Arthur slumped with relief. He was innocent. He hadn't put the envelope in the trash.

We try to keep it down at night.
People will complain if you don't keep it down.
We don't need to keep it down when you're outside.
When I was a kid, my friends and I used to go to a Korean fast food place.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^뤄껄]
공간의, 지역의, 현지의
(인체의) 일부에 대한
(특정 지역에 사는) 주민, 현지인
voca.means_en:
Local means existing in or belonging to the area where you live, or to the area that you are talking about.
Local government is elected by people in one area of a country and controls aspects such as education, housing, and transport within that area.
A local anaesthetic or condition affects only a small area of your body.
Your local is a pub which is near where you live and where you often go for a drink.

There is a small local park nearby.
Let's go out to the local park.
How do I get to the local park?
to think about something that has happened in your past\nLooking back, it was a big deal to go there when I was young.\n
to read something quickly\nto examine a collection of things or what is inside something\n
Someone's nephew is the son of their sister or brother.\nSophie: You know I love babies. I'm delighted that I'll have a niece or nephew. \n
the New Look a fashion in women's clothes introduced in 1947, characterized by long full skirts\nWhen the work was finished, the apartment looked brand new. I was very happy with the new look.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^넥st]
(시간, 순서, 공간상으로 바로 무엇) 다음/뒤/옆의
그 다음/뒤에, 그리고는
(~ 뒤에 그) 다음으로 가장 좋은, 큰, 중요한 등
다음 사람/것
voca.means_en:
next / nearest
The next period of time, event, person, or thing is the one that comes immediately after the present one or after the previous one.
You use next in expressions such as next Friday, next day and next year to refer, for example, to the first Friday, day, or year that comes after the present or previous one.
The next place or person is the one that is nearest to you or that is the first one that you come to.
The thing that happens next is the thing that happens immediately after something else.
When you next do something, you do it for the first time since you last did it.
You use next to say that something has more of a particular quality than all other things except one. For example, the thing that is next best is the one that is the best except for one other thing.
You use after next in expressions such as the week after next to refer to a period of time after the next one. For example, when it is May, the month after next is July.
If you say that you do something or experience something as much as the next person, you mean that you are no different from anyone else in the respect mentioned.
You use next to before a negative, or a word that suggests something negative, to mean almost, but not completely.

If a room or building is next door, it is the next one to the right or left.
The people next door are the people who live in the house or flat to the right or left of yours.
If you refer to someone as the boy next door or the girl next door, you mean that they are pleasant and respectable but rather dull.
Someone's niece is the daughter of their sister or brother.\nSophie: You know I love babies. I'm delighted that I'll have a niece or nephew. \n
used to say that something is not important or not a problem\n

voca.means_ko: 더 이상 ~이 아닌, \n이미 ~ 아니다\n더 이상 ~하지 않다.
voca.means_en: used to say that something which was possible or true before is not now\nAssistant: I'm sorry, but we no longer sell this item.\n

effect / result / consequence / outcome / repercussion
The outcome of an activity, process, or situation is the situation that exists at the end of it.
I hope you are happy with the outcome.

voca.means_ko:
[^페이s]
(걸음, 달리기, 움직임의) 속도, 걷는 속도, 페이스, 
보폭(1보), 속도감
(특히 초조해서, 또는 잔뜩 화가나서) 서성거리다
(일의) 속도/리듬을 유지하다
voca.means_en:
The pace of something is the speed at which it happens or is done.
Your pace is the speed at which you walk.
A pace is the distance that you move when you take one step.
If you pace a small area, you keep walking up and down it, because you are anxious or impatient.
If you pace yourself when doing something, you do it at a steady rate.

voca.means_ko: 의식을 잃다, 기절하다, 죽다, \n내놓다, 분배/배포 하다
voca.means_en:
to become unconscious
Jason: How much do you usually drink?
Lisa: I don't really know. I always pass out. But I'm a social drinker.
People go tenting there, and have barbecues in designated areas. It's a great place to enjoy the breeze and a fun place to go people-watching.\n
Mr. Read sighed. "Only the piecrust didn't survive."\n
Sometimes, for a change of pace, we rearrange the furniture in the apartment. Last spring, I also bought some potted plants for decoration.\n

voca.means_ko:
[p^롸핏t]
(금전적인) 이익, 수익, 이윤, 순익, 수입
이득, 이익,
이익을 얻다, 득을 보다
voca.means_en:
A profit is an amount of money that you gain when you are paid more for something than it cost you to make, get, or do it.
If you profit from something, you earn a profit from it.
If you profit from something, or it profits you, you gain some advantage or benefit from it.
Seller: I'm not making any profit at that price. How about $130?

If something is done properly, it is done in a correct and satisfactory way.
If someone behaves properly, they behave in a way that is considered acceptable and not rude.
B : I just don't know how to dress up properly for clubbing.

voca.means_ko:
[^뤼어뤠인쥐]
재배열하다, 재배치하다, 
(몸의 자세를) 바꾸다
(행사 시간, 날짜, 장소 등을) 재조정하다
voca.means_en:
If you rearrange things, you change the way in which they are organized or ordered.
If you rearrange a meeting or an appointment, you arrange for it to take place at a different time to that originally intended.
Sometimes, for a change of pace, we rearrange the furniture in the apartment.
If you redo a piece of work, you do it again in order to improve it or change it.\n

voca.means_ko:
[뤼^두s]
(규모, 크기, 양 등을) 줄이다, 축소하다
체중을 줄이다, 살을 빼다
줄이다, 감소시키다, 낮추다
voca.means_en:
If you reduce something, you make it smaller in size or amount, or less in degree.
If someone is reduced to a weaker or inferior state, they become weaker or inferior as a result of something that happens to them.
If you say that someone is reduced to doing something, you mean that they have to do it, although it is unpleasant or embarrassing.
If something is changed to a different or less complicated form, you can say that it is reduced to that form.
If you reduce liquid when you are cooking, or if it reduces, it is boiled in order to make it less in quantity and thicker.
If someone or something reduces you to tears, they make you feel so unhappy that you cry.
Relatively means to a certain degree, especially when compared with other things of the same kind.\n

The food was relatively cheap.
These tickets are relatively cheap.
I'm looking for a hotel that is relatively cheap.
used when you are comparing something with all similar things\n
If someone renovates an old building, they repair and improve it and get it back into good condition.\nI remember renovating my apartment before I moved in. We redid the floors.\n

A restaurant is a place where you can eat a meal and pay for it. In restaurants your food is usually served to you at your table by a waiter or waitress.
I have been to many high-end restaurants.
It's best to make a reservation for a high-end restaurant.
We went to a high-end restaurant for her birthday.

to make something clean by washing it in water
to remove something such as soap from something else with water
Then he began rinsing out Pal's food dish.

A sandwich usually consists of two slices of bread with a layer of food such as cheese or meat between them.
If you sandwich two things together with something else, you put that other thing between them. If you sandwich one thing between two other things, you put it between them.
On the way back, do you want me to get anything for you? A sandwich or coffee, maybe? 
That's very sweet of you. A sandwich sounds great to me.

voca.means_ko:
[슬^럼p]
(가치, 수량, 가격 등이) 급감/급락/폭락 하다
털썩 앉다, 푹 쓰러지다
불황
voca.means_en:
If something such as the value of something slumps, it falls suddenly and by a large amount.
If you slump somewhere, you fall or sit down there heavily, for example because you are very tired or you feel ill.
A slump is a time when many people in a country are unemployed and poor.
Arthur slumped with relief. He was innocent. He hadn't put the envelope in the trash.
You use somewhat to indicate that something is the case to a limited extent or degree.\nB : I'm disappointed with the movie. I mean, the story somewhat bizarre.\n

voca.means_ko: [^쑤붸늬어r]\n(휴가지 등에서 사는) 기념품, 선물\n기념품, 선물, 추억
voca.means_en: A souvenir is something which you buy or keep to remind you of a holiday, place, or event.\nLisa: I think this will make a good souvenir. I'll take it.\n

A spacious room or other place is large in size or area, so that you can move around freely in it.
The house felt more spacious.
The hotel room was very spacious.
I want to move to a more spacious apartment.

If people starve, they suffer greatly from lack of food which sometimes leads to their death.
To starve someone means not to give them any food.
If a person or thing is starved of something that they need, they are suffering because they are not getting enough of it.
Jason: Are you sure? You'll be starving in the afternoon.

voca.means_ko:
두드러지다, 명백하다
눈에 띄다, 잘 보이다
(~에서) 튀어나오다, ~을 내밀다.
voca.means_en:
to be further out than something else; to be partly outside something such as a container
to be very noticeable or easy to see
Arthur put down his backpack on the counter. One corner of Mr. Haney's envelope was sticking out of the flap.
If you refer to the storage of something, you mean that it is kept in a special place until it is needed.\nStorage is the process of storing data in a computer.\n

The storage closet saves up a lot of space.
We keep lots of things in the storage closet.
We should put these boxes in the storage closet.
A stove is a piece of equipment which provides heat, either for cooking or for heating a room.\nSuddenly the water on the stove began bubbling over.\n
immediately; without delay\nAssistant: We'll send your model straight away.\n

A street is a road in a city, town, or village, usually with houses along it.
You can use street or streets when talking about activities that happen out of doors in a town rather than inside a building.
If someone is streets ahead of you, they are much better at something than you are.
If you talk about the man in the street or the man or woman in the street, you mean ordinary people in general.
They also had different types of Korean street food. Everything was relatively cheap.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^섭젝t]
(논의 등의) 주제, (다뤄지고 있는) 문제, 사안,
학과, 과목
(그림, 사진 등의) 대상, 소재
연구/실험 대상, 피험자
주어
(특히 나쁜 영향을 받아) ~ 될 수 있다. ~ 당할 수 있다.
~의 권한 아래 있는, 지배를 받는
(다른 국가에) 종속된
(다른 국가, 집단을, 특히 무력으로) 지배하에 두다, 종속시키다
voca.means_en:
The subject of something such as a conversation, letter, or book is the thing that is being discussed or written about.
Someone or something that is the subject of criticism, study, or an investigation is being criticized, studied, or investigated.
A subject is an area of knowledge or study, especially one that you study at school, college, or university.
In an experiment or piece of research, the subject is the person or animal that is being tested or studied.
An artist's subjects are the people, animals, or objects that he or she paints, models, or photographs.
In grammar, the subject of a clause is the noun group that refers to the person or thing that is doing the action expressed by the verb. For example, in 'My cat keeps catching birds', 'my cat' is the subject.
The people who live in or belong to a particular country, usually one ruled by a monarch, are the subjects of that monarch or country.
To be subject to something means to be affected by it or to be likely to be affected by it.
If someone is subject to a particular set of rules or laws, they have to obey those rules or laws.
If you subject someone to something unpleasant, you make them experience it.

Surf is the mass of white bubbles that is formed by waves as they fall upon the shore.
If you surf, you ride on big waves in the sea on a special board.
If you surf the Internet, you spend time finding and looking at things on the Internet.
If you describe something as teeny, you are emphasizing that it is very small.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^티-더r]
(넘어질 듯이) 불안정하게 서다/움직이다
시소놀이를 하다, 위아래로 움직이다
상하의 움직임, 동요
voca.means_en: Teeter is used in expressions such as teeter on the brink and teeter on the edge to emphasize that something seems to be in a very unstable situation or position.\nIf someone or something teeters, they shake in an unsteady way, and seem to be about to lose their balance and fall over.\n
Teeth is the plural of tooth.\n
Assistant: I'm terribly sorry. I think we made a mistake and sent you the wrong model.\n

People in different countries speak different languages. It can be tricky to have a conversation with the locals.
When I traveled overseas last year, the locals didn't speak a word of English or Korean.
What do the locals usually eat?
She trusts the locals more than the tour guides.

voca.means_ko: 잠에 들지 못하고 계속 목을 뒤치닥거리는 것\n뒤척이다, 잠들지 못하다
voca.means_en: I suffered badly from jet lag. I couldn't enjoy myself to the fullest, because I was so sleepy. At night in bed, I tossed and turned because I was wide awake.\n

You can use unfortunately to introduce or refer to a statement when you consider that it is sad or disappointing, or when you want to express regret.\nAssistant: I'm sorry. But unfortunately you have to wait until 2 P.M.\n

Something that is unique is the only one of its kind.
You can use unique to describe things that you admire because they are very unusual and special.
If something is unique to one thing, person, group, or place, it concerns or belongs only to that thing, person, group, or place.
Assistant: Of course! Since it's made by hand, it's very unique and it's the only one in the world.

voca.means_ko:
~을 위해 내놓은
~을 위해 (특히 후로보) 고려되고 있는
(어떤 활동을) 기꺼이 하려고 하는
~ 하고 싶은
voca.means_en:
on offer for something
being considered for something, especially as a candidate
willing to take part in a particular activity
I'm up for some pizza tonight. How about you?
The utility of something is its usefulness.\nA utility is an important service such as water, electricity, or gas that is provided for everyone, and that everyone pays for.\n

There is a utility room next to the kitchen.
I put the laundry rack in the utility room.
Please turn on the light in the utility room.

If you refer to someone's vanity, you are critical of them because they take great pride in their appearance or abilities.
We have a vanity in the bedroom.
I do my makeup in front of my vanity.
There is a mirror on top of the vanity.

If you say that there are various things, you mean there are several different things of the type mentioned.
If a number of things are described as various, they are very different from one another.
When I was a kid, my friends and I used to go to a Korean fast food place. It was right in front of our school, and we went there after class. I ate various types of noodle and rice dishes there.

Wallpaper is thick coloured or patterned paper that is used for covering and decorating the walls of rooms.
Wallpaper is the background on a computer screen.
If someone wallpapers a room, they cover the walls with wallpaper.

clean / wash / rinse / cleanse / dry-clean / bathe
If you wash something, you clean it using water and usually a substance such as soap or detergent.
Everything seemed washed with silver.
If you wash or if you wash part of your body, especially your hands and face, you clean part of your body using soap and water.
If a sea or river washes somewhere, it flows there gently. You can also say that something carried by a sea or river washes or is washed somewhere.
The wash of a boat is the wave that it causes on either side as it moves through the water.

A washer is a thin flat ring of metal or rubber which is placed over a bolt before the nut is screwed on.
A washer is the same as a washing machine.
There is also a small utility room next to the kitchen. That's where we keep the washer.
A wastebasket is the same as a wastepaper basket.\nThe envelope teetered for a moment-and then fell into the wastebasket.\n

voca.means_ko: [웨어^륀]\n(의문사) 어디에, 어느 점에서\n(관계사) 거기서, 그 점에서
voca.means_en: Wherein means in which place or thing.\nWherein means in which part or respect.\n

voca.means_ko:
[윗치^에버r]
어느 쪽이든 ~ 한 것, 
누구든 ~ 한 사람
어느 ~ 이든, 
이느 쪽을 ~ 하든
voca.means_en: You use whichever in order to indicate that it does not matter which of the possible alternatives happens or is chosen.\nYou use whichever to specify which of a number of possibilities is the right one or the one you mean.\n
Whilst means the same as the conjunction while.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^윕pt]
매맞은, 
(섞어서 저어) 거품을 일게 한
휘저어 거품이 나게 한

[^윗쉬와쉬]
(음식이) 싱거운, 묽은,
김빠진 이야기, 시시한 이야기
우유부단한, 흐리멍덩한, 시시한, 하찮은
voca.means_en: If you say that someone is wishy-washy, you are critical of them because their ideas are not firm or clear.\n

voca.means_ko:
[^위쓰]
~와 함께, ~을 가진, ~ 을 써서, ~을 포함하여
(이유, 결과를 나타냄)
~함에 따라, ~와 더불어/함께
~와 같은 방향으로, (흐름 등을) 따라/타고
~에도 불구하고
voca.means_en:
If one person is with another, they are together in one place.
If something is put with or is with something else, they are used at the same time.
If you do something with someone else, you both do it together or are both involved in it.
If you fight, argue, or compete with someone, you oppose them.
If you do something with a particular tool, object, or substance, you do it using that tool, object, or substance.
If someone stands or goes somewhere with something, they are carrying it.
Someone or something with a particular feature or possession has that feature or possession.
If something is filled or covered with a substance or with things, it has that substance or those things in it or on it.
If you are, for example, pleased or annoyed with someone or something, you have that feeling towards them.
You use with to indicate what a state, quality, or action relates to, involves, or affects.
You use with when indicating the way that something is done or the feeling that a person has when they do something.

voca.means_ko: [^k뤠센t]\n초승달 모양\n크레센트 (집이 죽 늘어서 있는 초승달 모양의 거리)
voca.means_en:
A crescent is a curved shape that is wider in the middle than at its ends, like the shape of the moon during its first and last quarters. It is the most important symbol of the Islamic faith.
Crescent is sometimes used as part of the name of a street or row of houses that is usually built in a curve.
His partly eaten hamburger sat on the edge of his plate like a crescent moon.
to become, or to make somebody/yourself, happier or more cheerful\nEven the fact that they were having hamburgers and potato puffs hadn’t cheered him up.\n

If you concentrate on something, or concentrate your mind on it, you give all your attention to it.
If something is concentrated in an area, it is all there rather than being spread around.
Concentrate is a liquid or substance from which water has been removed in order to make it stronger, or to make it easier to store.

voca.means_ko: [컨^퓌겨뤠이션]\n배열, 배치, 배열/배치 형태\n구성, 형상, 상대적 배치, 요소의 조합
voca.means_en: A configuration is an arrangement of a group of things.\nThe configuration of a computer system is way in which all its parts, such as the hardware and software, are connected together in order for the computer to work.\n
If you configure a piece of computer equipment, you set it up so that it is ready for use.\n

voca.means_ko:
[컨^퍼r-엄]
(특히 증거를 들어) 사실임을 보여주다, 확인해 주다
(지위, 합의 등을) 확정하다, 공식화하다
확인하다, 입증하다, 승인하다
voca.means_en:
If something confirms what you believe, suspect, or fear, it shows that it is definitely true.
If you confirm something that has been stated or suggested, you say that it is true because you know about it.
If you confirm an arrangement or appointment, you say that it is definite, usually in a letter or on the telephone.
If someone is confirmed, they are formally accepted as a member of a Christian church during a ceremony in which they say they believe what the church teaches.
If something confirms you in your decision, belief, or opinion, it makes you think that you are definitely right.
If someone confirms their position, role, or power, they do something to make their power, position, or role stronger or more definite.
If something confirms you as something, it shows that you definitely deserve a name, role, or position.

voca.means_ko: [^데퍼넛리]\n(강조의 의미로 쓰여) 분명히, 틀림없이, 확실하게, 반드시
voca.means_en: You use definitely to emphasize that something is the case, or to emphasize the strength of your intention or opinion.\nIf something has been definitely decided, the decision will not be changed.\n

If you delay doing something, you do not do it immediately or at the planned or expected time, but you leave it until later.
To delay someone or something means to make them late or to slow them down.
If you delay, you deliberately take longer than necessary to do something.
If there is a delay, something does not happen until later than planned or expected.
Delay is a failure to do something immediately or in the required or usual time.

voca.means_ko: [^풱t]\n(~라는) 점, 실상, 실제, \n(특히 입증할 수 있는) 사실
voca.means_en:
You use the fact that after some verbs or prepositions, especially in expressions such as in view of the fact that, apart from the fact that, and despite the fact that, to link the verb or preposition with a clause.
You use the fact that instead of a simple that-clause either for emphasis or because the clause is the subject of your sentence.
You use in fact, in actual fact, or in point of fact to indicate that you are giving more detailed information about what you have just said.
When you refer to something as a fact or as fact, you mean that you think it is true or correct.
Facts are pieces of information that can be discovered.

If you huff, you indicate that you are annoyed or offended about something, usually by the way that you say something.\nIf someone is in a huff, they are behaving in a bad-tempered way because they are annoyed and offended.\n

A moat is a deep, wide channel dug round a place such as a castle and filled with water, in order to protect the place from attack.\nUsually he piled the potato puffs into a castle wall and then lined up the green beans like alligators in the moat.\n

If you peek at something or someone, you have a quick look at them, often secretly.
Jack and Annie crept to the cave and peeked inside.
Every time he looked up, he saw the envelope peeking at him from the wastebasket.

voca.means_ko: [^파일]\n(위로 차곡차곡) 쌓아올린 것, 더미, 다수, 대량\n~을 쌓다, 싣다, 저축하다, 늘리다
voca.means_en:
A pile of things is a mass of them that is high in the middle and has sloping sides.
A pile of things is a quantity of things that have been put neatly somewhere so that each thing is on top of the one below.
If you talk about a pile of something or piles of something, you mean a large amount of it.
If you pile things somewhere, you put them there so that they form a pile.
If something is piled with things, it is covered or filled with piles of things.
"From that pile of furry skins" said Annie, pointing.
Hay was piled in the corners.
As he swept everything into a neat pile, he felt good.
damage or loss of quality because of normal use\n"Are you trying to save wear and tear on your teeth, Arthur?" asked his mother.\n

voca.means_ko:
[카r펫t]
카펫, 양탄자
(방의 크기대로 바닥 전체에 까는) 카펫, 융단
융단(처럼 푹신하게 깔린 것)
카펫을 깔다
(~을 융단처럼 푹신하게) 덮다
voca.means_en:
A carpet is a thick covering of soft material which is laid over a floor or a staircase.
A carpet of something such as leaves or plants is a layer of them which covers the ground.
If a floor or a room is carpeted, a carpet is laid on the floor.
If the ground is carpeted with something such as leaves or plants, it is completely covered by them.

voca.means_ko:
[슈^뤠d]
조각, 단편, 아주 조금, 근소
(가늘고 작은) 조각,
~을 갈가리 찢다, 잘게 자르다
voca.means_en:
If you shred something such as food or paper, you cut it or tear it into very small, narrow pieces.
If you cut or tear food or paper into shreds, you cut or tear it into small, narrow pieces.
If there is not a shred of something, there is not even a small amount of it.
But tonight he had only stamped the puffs and beans down with his fork. They looked like little shredded carpets.

voca.means_ko:
[^메쉬]
(가축용의) 삶은 곡물 사료
(맥주 등을 만들기 위한) 뜨거운 물과 맥아/엿기름 혼합물
(부드럽게) 으깬 음식
(음식을 부드럽게) 으깨다
voca.means_en:
If you mash food that is solid but soft, you crush it so that it forms a soft mass.
Mash is mashed potato.
"All that mashing. You still have to eat them, you know. We don't want to waste food."

voca.means_ko: [s^꿔r엄]\n(초조하거나 불편하거나 하여 몸을) 꿈틀/꼼지락 대다\n몹시 당혹해 하다, 창피해 하다
voca.means_en:
If you squirm, you move your body from side to side, usually because you are nervous or uncomfortable.
If you squirm, you are very embarrassed or ashamed.
It twisted and squirmed.
Arthur squirmed in his chair. "We worked hard in school today."
But tonight he had only stamped the puffs and beans down with his fork.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s^왈로우]
(음식 등을) 삼키다, (목구멍으로) 넘기다, 
(특히 초조해서) 마른침을 삼키다, 
(특히 돈을) 다 써버리다,/까먹다, 
(사실로) 받아들이다, 믿다, 감수/감내하다
제비
voca.means_en:
If you swallow something, you cause it to go from your mouth down into your stomach.
If you swallow, you make a movement in your throat as if you are swallowing something, often because you are nervous or frightened.
If someone swallows a story or a statement, they believe it completely.
A swallow is a kind of small bird with pointed wings and a forked tail.
Dinner was hard to swallow.
